text: Raptor Comply represents a strategic expansion by MIT-founded solar software company Raptor Maps into the NERC CIP compliance market, launching October 30, 2025 to address a regulatory inflection point: May 2026 enforcement deadlines that will bring over 1,000 previously exempt renewable energy facilities under federal cybersecurity mandates. The platform targets small-to-medium power generators (20-1500+ MW) struggling with fragmented compliance tools, offering purpose-built automation at $839-$2,490/month versus enterprise GRC platforms requiring months of implementation and significantly higher costs.
title: Raptor Comply: Strategic Context Brief

text:
## Company origins trace from MIT aerospace labs to solar dominance
Raptor Maps was founded in 2015 by three MIT aerospace engineers—Nikhil Vadhavkar (CEO, PhD candidate in bioastronautics), Eddie Obropta (CTO, B.S./M.S. in Aeronautics and Astronautics), and Forrest Meyen—in the MIT Man-Vehicle Laboratory. The company won the MIT $100K Entrepreneurship Competition grand prize in May 2015, initially targeting precision agriculture through drone-based thermal imaging.
The pivot to solar came organically when solar farm operators discovered the platform's thermal imaging capabilities. Working from Greentown Labs (North America's largest cleantech incubator), the founders recognized stronger product-market fit in solar O&M, where operators were purchasing $20,000-30,000 drones but lacking software to analyze inspection data at scale. The company graduated from Y Combinator (Summer 2016) and has since raised approximately $62-65 million across multiple rounds:
Series A (August 2020): $5M led by Blue Bear Capital and Data Point Capital
Series B (April 2022): $22M led by MacKinnon, Bennett & Co., with participation from Microsoft Climate Innovation Fund
Series C (December 2024): $35M led by Maverix Private Equity
Today Raptor Maps monitors approximately 125 GW of solar assets across 45+ countries, covering roughly 200 million solar panels (~2% of global installations). Major customers include Tesla, SOLV Energy, Enel Green Power, and Cypress Creek Renewables. The company employs 119-156 people, primarily based at Greentown Labs in Somerville, Massachusetts.
title: Raptor Comply: Strategic Context Brief

text:
## Regulatory expansion creates urgent compliance demand
FERC Order 901 and subsequent NERC rule changes have fundamentally expanded which power generation facilities must comply with Critical Infrastructure Protection (CIP) cybersecurity standards. The core threshold change dropped mandatory registration requirements from ≥75 MVA at ≥100 kV to ≥20 MVA at ≥60 kV for inverter-based resources (IBRs), capturing over 1,000 previously exempt renewable energy facilities.
The new Category 2 IBR classification encompasses solar, wind, and battery storage facilities between 20-75 MVA—assets that historically operated without NERC oversight. NERC begins identifying these facilities for registration in May 2025, with full enforcement commencing May 2026. Additional enforcement milestones include:
CIP-015-1 (Internal Network Security Monitoring): Effective September 2, 2025
CIP-003-9 (Security Management Controls): Enforcement begins April 1, 2026
Full FERC Order 901 implementation: January 1, 2030
These regulatory changes respond directly to grid reliability incidents caused by IBR performance failures. Since 2016, over 15,000 MW of unexpected generation loss has occurred from IBR-related disturbances. The June 2022 Odessa II event—triggered by a lightning arrestor fault—caused 2,555 MW of generation loss from 14 different solar sites, nearly reaching ERCOT's largest allowable event threshold. Root causes included improper inverter protection settings, inadequate voltage ride-through performance, and poor model accuracy.
Enforcement has intensified correspondingly. The Duke Energy $10 million settlement (January 2019) remains the reference case: 127 CIP violations between 2015-2018, including 13 classified as serious risk—failures to revoke terminated employee access, firewalls permitting unencrypted remote access, and deficient security patch programs. NERC penalties increased 20% in 2024 compared to the prior year, with maximum penalties now reaching $1.54 million per day per violation.
title: Raptor Comply: Strategic Context Brief

text:
## Target customers face tool fragmentation and resource constraints
Raptor Comply targets two primary segments: small-to-medium power generation owners/operators (typically 20-1500+ MW) who manage NERC compliance internally, and Managed Security Service Providers (MSSPs) seeking a technology backbone for compliance delivery. The platform serves solar, wind, battery storage, natural gas, and hydro facilities.
Three distinct user personas experience compliance pain differently:
Compliance Managers struggle with audit preparation across evolving standards. Their workflow involves building compliance calendars, maintaining program coverage across all requirements, and coordinating evidence collection—often described as a "monumental task for even experienced utilities." One Compliance Manager noted: "That's a very nice feature—I haven't seen anything like that—a step by step that builds you a whole compliance calendar."
OT Engineering Managers bear the operational burden of evidence documentation. As one stated: "Right now, it's all very manual—taking screenshots and then emailing our team." They duplicate effort between operational execution and compliance documentation, with no automated capture of evidence as work occurs.
IT/Security teams face integration challenges across fragmented systems. A Technology Executive summarized: "The whole approach is a gap. We are using a hodgepodge of solutions."
Industry statistics underscore the problem's scale:
92% of compliance teams use 3+ different tools
96% report struggling to keep pace with compliance demands
5+ hours spent weekly on manual evidence collection
$62,500 estimated annual cost of manual evidence collection
$110,000+ FERC-estimated cost to establish a Low Impact NERC CIP program
$379,000+ for Medium Impact entities
CIP-004 (Personnel and Training) ranks among the most violated standards due to strict 24-hour timelines for revoking terminated employee access—a process particularly error-prone with spreadsheet-based tracking. CIP-007 (System Security Management) logged 108 serious/moderate risk noncompliance filings in 2022 alone.
title: Raptor Comply: Strategic Context Brief

text:
## Competitive positioning emphasizes speed and multi-team collaboration
Raptor Comply differentiates against enterprise GRC platforms (ServiceNow, MetricStream, LogicGate) on three dimensions: implementation speed, price accessibility, and purpose-built architecture for NERC CIP specifically.
Implementation timeline: The platform claims 2-3 weeks to operational readiness versus the 6-12 months typical of enterprise deployments. Marketing materials state: "Traditional compliance tools take months to set up because you start with a blank slate. Our platform comes ready to use—with NERC CIP task schedules, templates based on what actually works, and workflows you can start using right away."
Pricing structure targets the underserved middle market:
Annual billing provides 12% savings; 30-day refund guarantees apply to Starter and Scale tiers.
Multi-team collaboration addresses the fundamental workflow gap. Most compliance software serves either compliance administrators (program management, evidence collection) or IT/OT operations teams (technical implementation)—never both. CEO Vadhavkar stated: "Generator operators shouldn't have to choose between compliance and operational efficiency as they architect for scale." The platform connects both teams in a unified system where evidence generates automatically as operations teams complete work, eliminating duplicate effort and email-based coordination.
title: Raptor Comply: Strategic Context Brief

text:
## Product capabilities span the NERC CIP compliance lifecycle
The platform architecture centers on five core capabilities designed to automate compliance workflows while maintaining SOC 2 Type II certification:
Asset Inventory Management organizes cyber systems and cyber assets across multi-facility fleets, enabling assignment to policies, tasks, and access requests. This supports the foundational CIP-002 requirement for BES Cyber System categorization.
Smart Policies digitize compliance programs using a library of 60+ internal controls. Multiple-choice configuration flows guide users through requirement coverage, with custom detail capabilities for organization-specific needs. Marketing claims 100% program coverage for supported standards.
Auto-Task Scheduling generates NERC CIP tasks automatically based on policy and program configuration. The compliance calendar builds programmatically, addressing the manual calendar maintenance burden compliance managers identified as a primary pain point.
Access Control Workflows provide configurable flows for physical perimeters, electronic perimeters, Transient Cyber Asset (TCA) access, and removable media—the access management categories where CIP-004 violations most commonly occur. Sharable secure links enable rapid field access for technicians.
Evidence Automation integrates evidence collection directly with task completion. When operations teams perform actions, evidence generates automatically—eliminating the screenshot-and-email workflows that consume 5+ hours weekly for many teams.
The platform supports Low Impact, Medium Impact, and High Impact facility classifications, with Category 2 IBR support specifically addressing the May 2026 enforcement deadline. Technical architecture is API-based with single-tenancy database deployment, role-based access control, and SSO support.
title: Raptor Comply: Strategic Context Brief

text:
## Strategic constraints define best-fit customer profiles
Several factors bound Raptor Comply's optimal positioning:
Best-fit customers operate multi-facility portfolios in the 20-1500+ MW range, lack dedicated compliance technology infrastructure, and face the Category 2 IBR May 2026 deadline. Organizations already invested in enterprise GRC platforms like ServiceNow likely fall outside the target market. The sweet spot appears to be operators who have historically managed compliance through spreadsheets and fragmented tools, now facing regulatory requirements that demand more systematic approaches.
Standards coverage focuses primarily on Low Impact and Category 2 IBR requirements at lower tiers, with Medium and High Impact support in the Enterprise tier. The platform emphasizes CIP-003 (Security Management Controls) given its April 2026 enforcement date for version 9. Operations & Planning (O&P) task support is listed as planned rather than currently available.
Integration requirements include API-based connectivity and Active Directory integration (Enterprise tier). The single-tenancy architecture and SOC 2 Type II certification address security concerns, though organizations with complex existing IT landscapes should evaluate integration depth.
Product maturity considerations warrant attention: Raptor Comply launched October 30, 2025—less than one month ago. No independent reviews exist on G2, Capterra, or similar platforms. Customer testimonials on the website use role titles rather than named companies or individuals. While parent company Raptor Maps has established credibility with major solar operators (Tesla, SOLV Energy, Enel Green Power), the compliance product itself lacks track record. Organizations evaluating the platform should request reference calls with pilot customers and validate implementation timeline claims against actual deployments.
Team sizing for prospects should include both compliance and operations personnel, given the multi-team collaboration value proposition. Organizations where compliance and IT/OT teams operate entirely separately may see reduced benefit from the unified platform approach.
title: Raptor Comply: Strategic Context Brief

text:
## Conclusion
Raptor Comply enters the market at a regulatory inflection point—the May 2026 Category 2 IBR deadline creates urgency for over 1,000 renewable energy facilities that have never faced NERC CIP compliance requirements. The platform's $839-$2,490/month pricing and 2-3 week implementation claims directly target the cost and complexity barriers that have historically limited compliance software adoption among smaller generators.
The strategic logic of Raptor Maps' expansion makes sense: deep existing relationships with solar/renewable operators, proven software development capabilities, and timing aligned with regulatory expansion affecting their core customer base. However, the October 2025 launch means the product lacks the deployment history and customer evidence that would validate marketing claims. Organizations facing imminent compliance deadlines must weigh the apparent product-market fit against the inherent risks of adopting newly launched software for regulatory obligations carrying $1.54 million per day penalty exposure.
title: Raptor Comply: Strategic Context Brief

text:
## The competitive landscape favors focused challengers
Enterprise GRC platforms have priced themselves out of the mid-market. MetricStream's licensing starts at $750,000+ annually, Archer requires hiring dedicated full-time experts for customization, and ServiceNow implementations extend months with significant IT involvement. One PeerSpot reviewer captured the market reality: "Archer is expensive compared to other GRC tools... the cost would be prohibitive for a small or medium-scale company."
The specialized NERC CIP tools (Industrial Defender, Tripwire, Network Perception) solve point problems—asset management, change detection, network analysis—but none delivers complete program management with the rapid time-to-value smaller utilities desperately need. No NERC CIP-specific vendor currently positions prominently on fast implementation, despite compliance teams reporting that audit preparation "can take a compliance team's full attention and time for weeks."
The most violated NERC CIP standards reveal where software can create immediate value: CIP-007 (System Security) accounts for 54% of violations, followed by CIP-010 (Configuration Management) at 27.5% and CIP-004 (Personnel & Training) at 18.5%. Common causes include missed 35-day patch windows, configuration drift detection failures, and the strict 24-hour access revocation requirement for terminated employees. These are precisely the workflows where automation delivers measurable ROI—automating patch management alone saves an estimated two hours per month per asset.
path: Strategic Growth Opportunities for Raptor Comply
title: Strategic Growth Opportunities for Raptor Comply

text:
## Adjacent regulatory frameworks offer natural expansion paths
Three adjacent compliance domains share substantial workflow overlap with NERC CIP and present viable expansion opportunities:
EU NIS2 Directive (effective October 2024) is the most direct international equivalent, classifying energy infrastructure as "high criticality" and requiring incident reporting within 24 hours, supply chain security assessments, and management-level accountability. Penalties reach €10 million or 2% of global turnover. The control categories—access management, risk assessment, incident response—map directly to NERC CIP requirements, enabling significant platform reuse with localized compliance content.
Australian AESCSF (Australian Energy Sector Cyber Security Framework) was built on the same DOE ES-C2M2 foundation as U.S. frameworks, creating particularly strong alignment. Raptor Maps already operates in 50+ countries including Australia, providing existing customer relationships and market presence to leverage for compliance product expansion.
Battery storage compliance (NFPA 855, UL 9540) represents an adjacent vertical with growing documentation requirements. As solar-plus-storage deployments accelerate, compliance workflows for safety certification, grid interconnection (IEEE 1547/2800), and fire code documentation could extend Raptor Comply's value proposition to the same customer base.
FERC Order 2222 for distributed energy resources creates additional opportunity, though implementation timelines vary significantly by RTO—CAISO completed in November 2024, while SPP won't finish until Q2 2030. DER aggregators face coordination requirements between RTOs, distribution utilities, and individual resources that software could streamline.
path: Strategic Growth Opportunities for Raptor Comply
title: Strategic Growth Opportunities for Raptor Comply

text:
## AI capabilities in GRC remain nascent—creating first-mover potential
The GRC industry is amid an AI transformation, but implementation remains early-stage. Gartner predicts over 50% of major enterprises will use AI for continuous regulatory compliance checks by 2025, up from less than 10% in 2021. Organizations implementing AI-assisted security automation report 62% improvement in compliance efficiency, yet 60% of GRC professionals still manage with manual processes.
Current AI applications in leading platforms cluster around four capabilities: predictive risk scoring (MetricStream's AiSPIRE identifies patterns in historical violations), automated evidence collection (Secureframe reports 80-90% evidence reuse across overlapping frameworks), natural language policy search (enabling queries by intent rather than keywords), and regulatory change monitoring (Archer's Compliance.ai acquisition tracks regulatory updates and auto-maps to internal controls).
Critical infrastructure cybersecurity monitoring is advancing rapidly. Research demonstrates LSTM neural networks combined with Random Forest algorithms achieving 99.8% accuracy in power system anomaly detection. The SANS 2024 ICS/OT Survey found incident detection time improved from "days" in 2019 to "hours" in 2024, while OT-specific monitoring adoption grew from 33% to 52%. Industrial Defender has spent 10+ years automating NERC CIP compliance with OT asset management, positioning as the established player in the OT-compliance intersection.
The differentiation opportunity for Raptor Comply lies in NERC CIP-specific AI—most GRC platforms are horizontal, applying generic AI to compliance broadly rather than training models on energy sector-specific patterns, violation histories, and audit outcomes. Predictive capabilities for upcoming CIP requirement changes (like CIP-015-1 for internal network security monitoring) could provide proactive compliance guidance that reactive tools cannot match.
path: Strategic Growth Opportunities for Raptor Comply
title: Strategic Growth Opportunities for Raptor Comply

text:
## Raptor Maps' Series C positioned growth, but Raptor Comply was separate
Raptor Maps' $35 million Series C (December 2024, led by Maverix Private Equity) funded three stated priorities: product development acceleration for solar automation, team expansion in software engineering and data science, and scaling Raptor Solar Sentry for O&M orchestration. Notably, Raptor Comply was not mentioned in the Series C announcement—it launched independently in October 2025, suggesting it may have been developed as a strategic extension of the platform's data infrastructure.
CEO Nikhil Vadhavkar's public statements reveal the strategic logic: "We've been working on the data model to apply AI to solar for many, many years... A system of record is a necessity for adopting AI in the renewable industry." The company has digitized 150+ GW of solar capacity across 50+ countries, creating the data foundation for compliance intelligence. CTO Eddie Obropta emphasized the platform approach: "Our platform embeds years of compliance expertise directly into operations. Teams don't need to start from scratch—they can implement proven security frameworks from day one."
The current team size is estimated at 75-115 employees across three continents, operating from headquarters at Greentown Labs in Somerville, Massachusetts, with a remote-first culture. Named customers span the solar value chain: Enel Green Power, Luminace (Brookfield's 1,400+ site distributed solar portfolio), Cypress Creek Renewables, and EPCs including McCarthy, SOLV Energy, and Rosendin Electric.
Raptor Comply's pricing is published and transparent—uncommon in enterprise GRC: Starter at $839/month (1 control center, 5 Low Impact facilities), Scale at $2,490/month (expanded capacity), and custom Enterprise pricing. This positions against enterprise platforms that hide pricing behind sales processes and professional services requirements.

text:
## Four strategic growth vectors emerge from the research
Vector 1: Capture IBR deadline urgency (now through May 2026). The Category 2 IBR enforcement deadline creates a 205-day window of heightened demand. FERC estimates $379,000+ for Medium Impact entities to establish NERC CIP programs and $110,000+ for Low Impact. Raptor Comply's claim of 30%+ cost reduction and 2-3 week deployment directly addresses the time-compressed buying cycle. Marketing should emphasize countdown urgency and deployment speed guarantees.
Vector 2: Enable the "land with compliance, expand to operations" motion. Early customer feedback indicates cross-sell potential: "What you're building here, it works beyond NERC CIP and it works beyond solar." Raptor Comply can serve as the entry point for customer relationships that expand into Raptor Solar Sentry for O&M automation. Conversely, existing Raptor Solar customers managing NERC-registered assets represent warm leads for compliance upsell.
Vector 3: Build MSSP channel partnerships. The target customer segment includes Managed Security Service Providers as a delivery platform. MSSPs serving multiple smaller utilities could standardize on Raptor Comply, creating recurring channel revenue and reducing customer acquisition costs. This channel strategy mirrors successful patterns in cybersecurity software distribution.
Vector 4: Prepare international regulatory modules. NIS2 enforcement across EU member states (23 countries received infringement notices for transposition delays) and AESCSF in Australia represent the highest-alignment international opportunities. Product investment in localized compliance content could leverage existing Raptor Maps international presence (50+ countries, 150+ GW digitized) to open new markets before competitors adapt.

Competitive positioning should exploit specific, documented pain points:
Against enterprise GRC platforms: "Enterprise power without enterprise complexity and cost." Cite the MetricStream $750K+ annual licensing, the Archer requirement for "hiring a full-time dedicated expert," and the ServiceNow "extended implementation timelines." Position transparent pricing and self-service configuration as antidotes.
Against point solutions: "Complete NERC CIP program management, not just monitoring." Tools like Tripwire (configuration), Network Perception (network analysis), and Netwrix (change auditing) solve narrow problems. Position Raptor Comply as the unified platform that eliminates multi-tool sprawl—particularly relevant given that 92% of compliance teams use 3+ tools.
Against generic GRC platforms: "Built specifically for power industry compliance." Vanta, Sprinto, and Drata automate SOC 2 and similar frameworks but lack NERC CIP-specific workflows. The pre-built 60+ internal controls, CIP-specific task scheduling, and evidence templates create differentiation.
The "quick time-to-value" positioning is genuinely differentiated—no NERC CIP vendor currently claims rapid deployment prominently. The "2-3 weeks" claim should be validated with early customer data and used aggressively in competitive situations where enterprise tools require months.

text:
## Conclusion: Strategic priorities for Growth PM consideration
The research reveals Raptor Comply entering a market with genuine unmet needs rather than manufactured differentiation. The compliance burden on smaller utilities is real ($110K+ setup costs), the enterprise tools are genuinely ill-suited (months-long implementations, $55K-$750K+ costs), and the regulatory timeline is fixed (May 2026 IBR enforcement).
Near-term growth priorities should focus on capturing the IBR deadline window, building reference customers across the three violated standards (CIP-007, CIP-010, CIP-004), and proving the time-to-value claims with published case studies. Medium-term opportunities include MSSP channel development, cross-sell integration with Raptor Solar Sentry, and international expansion to NIS2/AESCSF markets.
The product-market fit signals are strong: early customer testimonials validate core value propositions, the pricing is aligned with mid-market budgets, and the parent company's data infrastructure provides a technical moat. The Growth PM challenge is execution—converting market opportunity into customer acquisition velocity before the May 2026 deadline passes and urgency dissipates.

text:
## Company Context
Raptor Maps is an MIT-founded solar software company (Y Combinator S16) that monitors 125 GW of solar assets across 45+ countries. The company raised a $35M Series C in December 2024, employs 75-115 people, and counts Tesla, Enel Green Power, and Cypress Creek Renewables as customers. Raptor Comply launched October 30, 2025—less than one month old with ~10 pilots and no independent reviews yet.
Pricing is transparent and mid-market focused: $839/month (Starter), $2,490/month (Scale), custom Enterprise. This undercuts enterprise GRC platforms by 10-100x while offering purpose-built NERC CIP functionality.
Primary target: Small-to-medium power generators (20-1500+ MW) managing NERC compliance internally — solar, wind, battery storage, natural gas, and hydro facilities. Specifically those facing the new Category 2 IBR requirements who've never had to comply before.
Secondary target: Managed Security Service Providers (MSSPs) who could use Raptor Comply as their technology backbone to serve multiple smaller utility clients.
Named Raptor Maps customers (parent company, not Raptor Comply specifically): Tesla, SOLV Energy, Enel Green Power, Cypress Creek Renewables, Luminace (Brookfield's 1,400+ site distributed solar portfolio). These existing relationships are warm leads for the compliance product upsell.
Who's NOT the target: Enterprises already invested in ServiceNow, MetricStream, or Archer — they've sunk cost into those platforms and won't switch for a new product.

## The Regulatory Catalyst
FERC Order 901 dropped mandatory registration thresholds from ≥75 MVA to ≥20 MVA for inverter-based resources (solar, wind, battery). Key enforcement milestones create urgency:
May 2025: NERC begins identifying Category 2 IBR facilities for registration
April 2026: CIP-003-9 (Security Management Controls) enforcement begins
May 2026: Full Category 2 IBR enforcement deadline
January 2030: Complete FERC Order 901 implementation
Penalties have teeth: Duke Energy paid $10M for 127 violations, and maximum penalties now reach $1.54M per day per violation.

Manual drudgery: 5+ hours weekly spent on manual evidence collection, primarily "taking screenshots and emailing our team."

NERC-specific point solutions (Industrial Defender, Tripwire, Network Perception): Solve narrow problems (asset management, change detection, network analysis) but don't deliver complete program management or fast time-to-value.

text:
## Strategic Recommendations: Raptor Comply 30-Day Growth Case Study
This is a resource-constrained launch into a deadline-driven market. The strategic through-line I'm building: demonstrate time-to-value so fast it becomes your competitive moat. Every onboarding decision, every experiment, every metric should ladder up to proving that Raptor Comply delivers compliance clarity faster than any alternative—including doing nothing.
Let me walk you through each decision with the reasoning behind it.
title: Raptor Comply Prep

text:
## PART 1: Onboarding & Activation
  The Activation Metric Decision
  I evaluated four candidate activation metrics against three criteria: predictive of conversion, achievable in <7 days, and demonstrates core value proposition.
  Option A: First Policy Configured. Shows engagement but not value delivery. A user could configure a policy incorrectly and still "activate"—this measures effort, not outcome. Weak predictor of conversion because it doesn't prove the product works.
  Option B: First Compliance Task Auto-Scheduled. Better—this proves the automation is functioning. But scheduling a task isn't the same as understanding your compliance posture. The user still hasn't experienced the "aha moment" of seeing their exposure.
  Option C: First Evidence Artifact Generated. This requires the user to complete a task and have the system capture evidence automatically. High-value signal, but takes too long—likely 2+ weeks given task scheduling cadences. Fails the <7 day requirement.
  Option D: Compliance Exposure Score Calculated. This means the user has entered their facility profile, asset inventory, and policy selections—and the system has returned a quantified view of their compliance gaps, upcoming deadlines, and risk exposure. This is the "aha moment."
  Before I walk through my activation metric recommendation, I want to flag that this assumes a product capability — the ability to generate a compliance exposure score from minimal input. If that feature exists or can be built, here's my recommendation. If not, I have a fallback metric I can discuss.
  My recommendation: Option D—Compliance Exposure Score Calculated within 5 minutes of substantive input.
Here's my reasoning. The documented pain point is that compliance teams face a "monumental task" just understanding where they stand. FERC estimates $110K+ just to establish a Low Impact program—much of that cost is assessment and planning before any actual compliance work. If Raptor Comply can show a user their exposure in minutes instead of weeks, that's the value demonstration that drives conversion.
  This also directly attacks competitor weakness. Enterprise GRC platforms require months of implementation before delivering any insight. Point solutions like Tripwire or Network Perception show technical data but don't translate it into compliance posture. "See your exposure in 5 minutes" is a claim no competitor can match.
  The tradeoff: this metric requires the user to input meaningful data (facility type, MW capacity, asset categories). If the input friction is too high, you'll see drop-off before activation. That's why the onboarding flow design is critical.
  The Onboarding Flow Design
  I considered four structural approaches:
  Approach 1: Linear Configuration Wizard. Walk users through asset inventory → policy selection → task scheduling step-by-step. Problem: this front-loads effort before value. Users invest 30+ minutes before seeing any return. High abandonment risk.
  Approach 2: Template-Based Quick Start. "You're a 50 MW solar facility in ERCOT—here's your pre-configured compliance program." Problem: too presumptive. Compliance managers need to trust that the system understands their specific situation. Templates feel generic.
  Approach 3: Import-and-Analyze. "Upload your existing asset spreadsheet and we'll map it." Problem: assumes users have clean data to import. The research shows they're using "hodgepodge solutions"—their data is scattered and inconsistent.
  Approach 4: Assessment-First (Diagnose Before Prescribe). Start with 5-7 questions that establish facility profile and compliance scope. Show the exposure score immediately. Then offer to "fix" the identified gaps through guided configuration.
  My recommendation: Approach 4—Assessment-First onboarding with immediate exposure scoring.
  The specific flow I'd design:
  Day 1, Minute 0-2: Facility Profile Quiz. Five multiple-choice questions: What's your total MW capacity? (dropdown: <20 MVA, 20-75 MVA, 75+ MVA). What's your interconnection voltage? (dropdown ranges). What generation type? (solar/wind/battery/gas/hydro). Are you currently NERC-registered? (yes/no/unsure). What's your current compliance approach? (spreadsheets/no formal program/enterprise GRC/consultant-managed).
  These questions take 90 seconds and accomplish two things: they segment the user into Low Impact vs. Medium Impact vs. Category 2 IBR, and they reveal their current pain level.
  Day 1, Minute 2-5: Instant Exposure Report. Based on those five answers, generate an exposure summary: "Based on your 45 MVA solar facility at 69kV, you fall under Category 2 IBR requirements effective May 2026. Here's what that means..." Show a visual dashboard with: applicable CIP standards (CIP-003-9, etc.), key deadlines (May 2026 registration, April 2026 CIP-003-9 enforcement), estimated compliance gap (percentage of requirements currently addressed based on their "current approach" answer), and penalty exposure range.
  This is the activation moment. The user now understands their situation in a way they didn't before signing up.
  Day 1, Minute 5-15: Guided Asset Inventory. Now that they've seen value, prompt them to add detail: "To refine your compliance roadmap, let's identify your BES Cyber Assets. How many inverters do you have? Do you have SCADA systems? Remote access points?" Use progressive disclosure—start with the minimum viable asset inventory (the categories required for CIP-002 classification), not a complete technical inventory.
  Day 2-3: Policy Configuration with Recommendations. Based on the asset inventory, pre-select recommended policies from the 60+ internal controls. "For Category 2 IBR facilities with remote access, we recommend these 12 policies. Review and customize, or accept defaults to continue." This leverages the "comes ready to use" positioning from their marketing.
  Day 4-7: First Task Assignment and Team Invitation. Generate the first compliance tasks based on policy configuration. Prompt user to invite their IT/OT counterpart: "Compliance works best when operations teams are connected. Invite your OT Engineering Manager to handle technical evidence collection."
  Top 3 Drop-Off Risks and Mitigations
  Risk 1: Asset Inventory Paralysis (Day 1, Minute 5-15).
The research shows compliance managers struggle because "it's all very manual—taking screenshots and emailing our team." They don't have clean asset data readily available. When the quiz ends and the system asks for asset details, users may stall because they need to gather information from other systems or colleagues.
  Mitigation: Offer a "Quick Start" path that uses facility-type defaults. "Don't have your asset inventory handy? We'll use typical assets for a 45 MW solar facility. You can refine later." This preserves momentum while allowing progressive refinement. Also provide a "save and continue later" with email reminder at 24 and 72 hours.
  Risk 2: Multi-Stakeholder Coordination Stall (Day 4-7).
Raptor Comply's value proposition depends on connecting compliance managers and IT/OT teams. But the compliance manager who signs up for the trial may not have authority to invite colleagues, or may face internal friction getting buy-in. This creates a ceiling on activation—single-user trials can't demonstrate the multi-team collaboration value.
  Mitigation: Design a single-user activation path that still delivers value. The exposure score and task scheduling work for solo users. Frame team invitation as "unlock advanced features" rather than a gate. Provide a "stakeholder briefing" one-pager the compliance manager can share internally: "Here's what I found using Raptor Comply—here's why we should trial it together."
  Risk 3: "I'll Come Back Later" Syndrome (Day 1, Any Point).
Compliance professionals are busy. They sign up with good intentions, get interrupted, and never return. The research cites "5+ hours weekly on manual evidence collection"—these are time-starved users.
  Mitigation: The 5-minute exposure score is the primary defense—deliver value before they leave. Secondary defense: behavioral email sequence triggered by drop-off points. If they complete the quiz but don't start asset inventory within 24 hours, send: "Your compliance exposure report is waiting. You're 83% ready for May 2026—here's what's missing." If they start asset inventory but don't finish, send: "You've identified 12 cyber assets. Add 3 more to complete your baseline and unlock task scheduling."
  Quantify progress and create completion momentum rather than generic "come back" nudges.
title: Raptor Comply Prep

text:
## PART 2: 30-Day Growth Execution Plan
  Strategic Constraints That Shape Experiment Selection
  Before picking experiments, let me name the constraints that eliminate certain options:
  $5K eliminates paid search. NERC CIP compliance keywords are expensive (enterprise GRC buyers) and Raptor Comply's brand awareness is zero. You'd burn budget on clicks from enterprises who aren't the target market.
  30 days eliminates SEO/content marketing. Content takes months to rank. You might publish content for credibility, but it won't drive trial signups in this window.
  Early stage means limited social proof. You can't run campaigns built on case studies and logos you don't have yet.
  May 2026 deadline creates urgency positioning. This is the hook—every experiment should reference the countdown.
  Before I walk through the three marketing experiments, I want to call out a zero-cost opportunity: Raptor Maps has existing relationships with solar operators like Tesla, Enel, and Cypress Creek. My first move would be working with sales to identify which of those customers manage NERC-registered assets and run a targeted outreach offering early access to Raptor Comply. This is our warmest, lowest-CAC channel and could generate reference customers before we spend a dollar on paid acquisition. Now, for the $5K budget...”
  The Three Experiments I'd Run
  Experiment 1: LinkedIn "Compliance Exposure Calculator" Lead Magnet ($2,000)
  Channel: LinkedIn Ads targeting compliance managers at power generation companies.
  Tactic: Promoted post driving to a gated "NERC CIP Compliance Exposure Calculator"—essentially a standalone version of the Day 1 assessment quiz. User answers 5 questions, gets an exposure report with their Category 2 IBR status, applicable standards, and May 2026 deadline. Report ends with: "Want to see your full compliance roadmap? Start your free trial of Raptor Comply."
  Why this experiment: It tests the core hypothesis that "see your exposure fast" resonates with the target audience. If compliance managers won't even complete a 5-question quiz for a free report, they won't complete trial onboarding. This is a lower-commitment way to validate the value proposition before optimizing the full trial flow.
  Budget allocation: $1,500 on LinkedIn ad spend (targeting: Job titles containing "compliance," "NERC," "reliability" at companies in Utilities, Renewable Energy, Power Generation industries; company size 51-1000; US geography). $500 reserved for creative iteration based on Week 1 performance. 
  Success criteria: 500+ quiz completions at <$3 cost per completion. 15%+ conversion from quiz completion to free trial signup (75+ trial signups from this channel). Track which quiz answers correlate with trial signup to refine targeting. 
  Experiment 2: Industry Newsletter Sponsorship ($1,500)
  Channel: Sponsored content in NERC-focused or renewable energy compliance newsletters.
  Tactic: Identify 2-3 newsletters that reach compliance professionals at power generators. Options include: Utility Dive's compliance coverage, POWER Magazine's newsletter, or regional reliability coordinator newsletters. Purchase a sponsored post or newsletter inclusion featuring the May 2026 deadline angle.
  Why this experiment: Newsletter audiences are pre-qualified—they've opted in to receive compliance content. This is "rented audience" that doesn't require building from scratch. It also tests whether the message resonates with an audience actively seeking compliance information (high intent) versus LinkedIn's broader professional audience (lower intent but larger scale).
  Budget allocation: $1,500 split across 2 newsletter placements in Weeks 2-3. Negotiate for inclusion of a trackable link to the free trial landing page.
  Success criteria: 3%+ click-through rate from newsletter to landing page (newsletters average 2-5% CTR for sponsored content). 25%+ conversion from click to trial signup. If one newsletter dramatically outperforms, reallocate remaining budget to double down.
  Experiment 3: "May 2026 Readiness" Webinar with MSSP Partner ($1,500)
  Channel: Co-marketed webinar with an MSSP or compliance consultant who serves the target market.
  Tactic: Partner with a managed security service provider or NERC compliance consulting firm to co-host a webinar: "May 2026 Category 2 IBR Deadline: What You Need to Know and How to Prepare." The MSSP provides credibility and brings their client list as attendees. Raptor Comply provides the platform demo as part of the "how to prepare" content.
  Why this experiment: This tests the MSSP channel hypothesis from the research. If MSSPs are willing to co-market, they're signaling potential for deeper partnership (reselling, referrals). It also generates higher-quality leads—webinar attendees who watch a 45-minute session have demonstrated genuine interest. The cost-per-lead will be higher, but conversion rates should be significantly better.
  Budget allocation: $500 for webinar platform/promotion. $500 for MSSP incentive (co-marketing fee or lead share agreement). $500 for post-webinar follow-up sequence and landing page optimization.
  Success criteria: 100+ registrations (co-marketing should bring 50+ from MSSP's network). 40%+ attendance rate (40+ live attendees). 25%+ conversion from attendee to free trial signup (10+ high-quality trial signups). Secondary goal: validate MSSP channel interest for future partnership development.
  Week-by-Week Execution Plan
  Week 1: Foundation and Experiment 1 Launch
  Days 1-2: Finalize the Compliance Exposure Calculator quiz and results page. This is the asset that powers Experiment 1 and serves as the activation mechanism within the trial. Build the landing page with May 2026 countdown prominently featured.
  Days 3-4: Launch LinkedIn campaign with 3 creative variants. Variant A emphasizes deadline urgency ("150 days until NERC CIP enforcement expands"). Variant B emphasizes cost savings ("Stop spending $110K on compliance setup"). Variant C emphasizes speed ("See your compliance exposure in 5 minutes").
  Days 5-7: Monitor initial performance. Pause underperforming variants, increase spend on winners. Begin outreach to newsletters for Experiment 2 placements.
  Week 2: Experiment 2 Launch and Experiment 1 Optimization
  Days 8-10: Confirm newsletter placements for Week 2-3. Finalize sponsored content copy—use learnings from Week 1 LinkedIn performance to inform messaging.
  Days 11-14: First newsletter placement goes live. Simultaneously, begin MSSP partner outreach for Experiment 3. Target 5-10 MSSPs with personalized outreach offering co-marketing partnership.
  End of Week 2 checkpoint: Review Experiment 1 data. Are quiz completions converting to trial signups? If <10% conversion, the trial onboarding flow needs work before scaling spend. If >20%, increase LinkedIn budget using the $500 reserve.
  Week 3: Experiment 3 Launch and Optimization
  Days 15-17: Confirm MSSP partner and webinar date (schedule for Day 21-24). Create webinar registration page and promotional assets.
  Days 18-21: Second newsletter placement goes live. Promote webinar through LinkedIn organic posts and to existing trial signups who haven't activated (re-engagement opportunity).
  Days 22-24: Host webinar. Capture registrant data and engagement metrics (questions asked, poll responses, demo section watch time).
  End of Week 3 checkpoint: Compare cost-per-trial-signup across all three experiments. You should have enough data to identify which channel is most efficient.
  Week 4: Double Down and Document
  Days 25-28: Reallocate remaining budget to best-performing channel. If LinkedIn is winning, increase spend and test new audiences (expand to job titles like "reliability coordinator," "grid compliance"). If newsletter is winning, book additional placements for post-trial-launch period. If webinar is winning, schedule second webinar and explore deeper MSSP partnership.
  Days 29-30: Compile learnings for case study presentation. Document what worked, what didn't, and hypotheses for next 30 days. Prepare metrics dashboard for ongoing monitoring.
  The Metrics Dashboard (5-8 Key Metrics)
  I'm organizing these in a funnel structure because that's how you'll diagnose problems:
  Top of Funnel (Awareness to Interest):
  Impressions by Channel — Are your experiments reaching the target audience?
  Click-Through Rate by Channel — Is the messaging resonating?
  Middle of Funnel (Interest to Trial):
3. Quiz Completions (Experiment 1 specific) — Are people engaging with the exposure calculator?
4. Trial Signups — The primary volume metric. Target: 150+ in 30 days across all channels.
5. Cost per Trial Signup by Channel — Efficiency metric for budget allocation decisions. Target: <$35 average (allows 150 signups on $5K budget).
  Bottom of Funnel (Trial to Activation):
6. Activation Rate (% of trial signups who reach Compliance Exposure Score within 7 days) — Target: 40%+. This is the leading indicator of trial-to-paid conversion.
7. Time to Activation — How many days/hours from signup to exposure score? Shorter is better. Target: median <2 days.
  Lagging Indicator:
8. Trial to Paid Conversion Rate — This won't be measurable in 30 days (trials need time to convert), but establish the tracking now. Industry benchmark for B2B SaaS free trials: 15-25%.
  One bonus metric I'd track informally: Qualitative feedback on the "aha moment." Add a single question after the exposure score: "How valuable was this compliance assessment?" (1-5 scale). This helps you understand if the activation mechanism is actually delivering perceived value or just checking a box.
title: Raptor Comply Prep

text:
## PART 3: LinkedIn Post
  Pick one of your marketing experiments. Write the actual LinkedIn post you'd publish to promote the free trial to compliance professionals at energy companies. Include post copy and any accompanying creative brief (image/video description if relevant).
  Which Experiment to Promote
  I'm recommending the LinkedIn post promote Experiment 1: the Compliance Exposure Calculator.
  Here's my reasoning: The calculator is the lowest-commitment entry point. It validates interest before asking for a trial signup. A LinkedIn post asking people to sign up for a free trial has more friction than a post offering a free assessment tool. Once they've completed the quiz and seen their exposure score, the trial signup becomes a natural next step.
  The webinar (Experiment 3) would also make a strong LinkedIn post, but it requires scheduling commitment and has a fixed date—limiting reach. The calculator is evergreen and can be promoted continuously.
  The LinkedIn Post
  Post Copy:
  In 150 days, NERC CIP enforcement expands to 1,000+ renewable energy facilities that have never faced federal cybersecurity mandates.
  If you operate solar, wind, or battery storage assets between 20-75 MVA, you're likely in scope for Category 2 IBR requirements starting May 2026.
  The question isn't whether you need a compliance program. It's whether you have time to build one.
  Most utilities spend $110K+ and 6+ months standing up a NERC CIP program from scratch. That timeline doesn't work when you have 150 days.
  We built a 5-minute Compliance Exposure Calculator to help you understand exactly where you stand:
  → Are you subject to the new IBR requirements?
→ Which CIP standards apply to your facility type?
→ What's your current compliance gap?
→ What deadlines are you racing against?
  No sales pitch. No commitment. Just clarity on what May 2026 means for your operations.
  [Link: See Your Compliance Exposure →]
  Creative Brief:
  Format: Single static image (LinkedIn's algorithm currently favors text-heavy posts with simple images over carousels or videos for B2B content).
  Visual concept: A countdown timer showing "150 DAYS" prominently, with the subhead "Until NERC CIP expands to 1,000+ renewable facilities." Below the countdown, a simple checklist graphic with three items: "Am I in scope? ✓" "Which standards apply? ✓" "What's my gap? ✓" with the CTA "Get your exposure score in 5 minutes."
  Color palette: Use Raptor Comply's brand colors (likely blues/greens given climate tech positioning). Avoid red/alarm colors—compliance professionals see enough fear-based marketing. Position this as clarity, not panic.
  Image dimensions: 1200 x 627 pixels (LinkedIn's recommended aspect ratio for link preview images).
title: Raptor Comply Prep

text:
## How These Parts Connect as a System
  Let me make explicit how these decisions reinforce each other:
  The activation metric (Compliance Exposure Score) directly shapes the lead magnet (Calculator). By defining activation as "seeing your exposure," I can test that value proposition before users even enter the trial. If the calculator converts well, the activation mechanism is validated. If it doesn't, I know to rethink the core value prop before spending more on acquisition.
  Week 1-2 results determine Week 3-4 strategy. If the LinkedIn calculator outperforms, I'd shift the webinar content to be calculator-focused ("See your live exposure score demo"). If newsletter outperforms LinkedIn, I'd reduce paid spend and invest in creating newsletter-worthy content for earned placements. The experiments are designed to generate learnings, not just leads.
  The MSSP webinar (Experiment 3) tests a channel hypothesis that affects post-30-day strategy. If MSSPs engage enthusiastically with co-marketing, the growth playbook shifts toward channel partnerships. If they're lukewarm, direct acquisition becomes the priority. This experiment is as much about strategic intelligence as lead generation.
  Drop-off mitigations connect to the metrics dashboard. The "Asset Inventory Paralysis" risk would show up as high quiz completion but low activation rate—users get the exposure score but stall on the next step. The "I'll Come Back Later" risk would show up as long time-to-activation. The dashboard is designed to diagnose which risk is actually occurring.
title: Raptor Comply Prep

text:
## Post presentation q&a
  Strategic Judgment Questions
  "Why these three experiments and not others?"
Be ready to explain what you didn't pick and why. You deprioritized paid search (expensive, wrong audience), SEO/content (too slow for 30 days), and events/conferences (logistically complex, budget doesn't support). Show you evaluated options, not just grabbed the first ideas.
  "What would you do differently with $20K? With $50K?"
They're testing if you can scale thinking. With $20K, you might add paid search for high-intent keywords, sponsor a second webinar, or hire a freelance content writer for SEO groundwork. With $50K, you might test a small field marketing event or regional utility conference sponsorship.
  "What's your biggest risk in this plan?"
Have a clear answer. Mine would be: "The biggest risk is that the fast time-to-value positioning doesn't resonate — if compliance managers don't care about speed and only care about cost or thoroughness, our messaging misses. That's why Experiment 1 tests the value prop before we scale spend."
  "What would make you abandon this strategy entirely?"
Shows you're not precious about your ideas. Answer: "If Week 1-2 data shows the exposure calculator gets completions but zero trial conversions, that tells me the value prop isn't compelling enough to drive action. I'd pause paid spend and do customer interviews to understand what's actually blocking them."
  Execution & Prioritization Questions
  "It's Day 15 and you've only generated 20 trial signups. What do you do?"
They want to see how you diagnose and respond. Answer: "First I'd look at where the funnel is breaking — are we getting impressions but no clicks (messaging problem), clicks but no quiz completions (landing page problem), or completions but no trial signups (value prop problem). The fix depends on where the drop-off is. If it's top-of-funnel, I'd test new creative. If it's bottom-of-funnel, I'd revisit the trial signup CTA and friction."
  "How would you prioritize if you only had 2 weeks instead of 4?"
Answer: "I'd cut Experiment 3 (webinar) entirely — it requires partner coordination and has a longer lead time. I'd focus all budget on Experiment 1 (LinkedIn calculator) and Experiment 2 (newsletter), which can launch faster and generate learnings quickly."
  "Who do you need to execute this plan?"
Show you've thought about cross-functional dependencies. Answer: "I'd need design support for the landing page and LinkedIn creative, engineering to build or validate the exposure calculator capability, sales to identify warm leads from Raptor Maps' customer base, and marketing ops to set up tracking and the email sequences."
  Product & Customer Questions
  "How do you know compliance managers actually care about speed?"
This is where your research pays off. Answer: "The research shows compliance teams spend 5+ hours weekly on manual evidence collection and describe audit prep as a 'monumental task.' FERC estimates 6+ months to stand up a program. The pain is time, not just money. Speed directly addresses that."
  "What if our target customer doesn't use LinkedIn?"
Fair challenge. Answer: "That's a hypothesis I'm testing with Experiment 1. If LinkedIn CTR is poor despite good targeting, that's a signal to shift budget to industry newsletters or direct outreach channels where compliance professionals are more active. The experiment is designed to learn, not just acquire."
  "How would you handle a customer who activates but then churns after the trial?"
Shows you're thinking beyond acquisition. Answer: "I'd want to understand why — was the product missing a key feature, did they hit a technical blocker, or did they just not have time to evaluate properly? I'd build a brief exit survey into the trial expiration flow and flag churned-but-activated users for a personal follow-up call."
  Metrics & Measurement Questions
  "How do you know if 40% activation rate is good or bad?"
Be honest that it's a benchmark. Answer: "40% is an industry benchmark for B2B SaaS free trials. Without Raptor Comply baseline data, I'd treat this as a starting hypothesis. If we hit 25%, that's still signal — and I'd dig into where users are dropping to improve it. The first 30 days are about establishing baselines, not hitting arbitrary targets."
  "What's the most important metric in your dashboard?"
Pick one and defend it. Answer: "Activation rate — it's the leading indicator that predicts everything downstream. High trial signups but low activation means we're acquiring the wrong users or the onboarding is broken. High activation suggests the product is delivering value and conversion will follow."
  "How would you attribute conversions across experiments?"
Shows you've thought about measurement rigor. Answer: "Each experiment has a unique entry point — LinkedIn drives to the calculator, newsletters drive to a trial landing page with UTM parameters, webinar attendees are tracked by registration. I'd use UTM tagging throughout and build a simple attribution view in the dashboard. For a 30-day sprint, first-touch attribution is good enough."
  Questions About You / Working Style
  "How did you approach this case study?"
Be honest about your process. You did deep research on the market, competitive landscape, and regulatory context before developing strategy. You considered multiple options for each decision and made explicit tradeoffs. You pressure-tested assumptions.
  "What would you want to learn in your first 30 days on the job?"
Answer: "I'd want to understand the current trial flow and where users are dropping off, talk to 5-10 pilot customers about what made them convert or hesitate, and understand engineering capacity for onboarding changes. My strategy is based on research — I'd want to validate it against internal data and customer reality."
  "What's a time you had to drive growth with limited resources?"
This is your Kunik story. You reduced time-to-value from 3 weeks to 5 days, built activation systems, and ran $100K pilots. Connect it directly: "At Kunik, I faced a similar challenge — early-stage product, limited budget, needed to prove value fast. I focused on reducing time-to-value because that was the unlock for conversion. I'd bring that same lens here."
  Curveball Questions
  "We actually already tried LinkedIn ads and they didn't work. Now what?"
Don't get defensive. Answer: "I'd want to understand what didn't work — was it targeting, creative, landing page, or the offer itself? If LinkedIn is proven dead for this audience, I'd reallocate that $2K to doubling down on newsletter sponsorships and testing a direct outreach campaign to Raptor Maps' existing customer base."
  "What if we told you the free trial is launching in 15 days, not 30?"
Shows you can adapt under pressure. Answer: "I'd simplify to one experiment — the LinkedIn calculator — and treat the other two as fast-follows for post-launch. I'd also prioritize the Raptor Maps customer outreach since that requires no creative production and can launch immediately."
  "Is there anything in our product or market you think we're getting wrong?"
Careful here — be constructive, not critical. Answer: "Based on my research, the multi-team collaboration value prop is strong but hard to demonstrate in a single-user trial. I'd want to explore how to give solo evaluators a taste of that value without requiring them to invite colleagues during the trial."
  Want me to do a mock Q&A with you where I play the interviewer and throw some of these at you?

text:
Hi Heba,
Great chatting with you today!
As mentioned, here are some helpful resources for the upcoming interviews. Let me know if you have any questions or want to hop on another call before your interviews. You got this!
Interview Logistics:
Your virtual on-site is 
  five independent 1 hour interviews.
The first 5 minutes of each interview is usually making introductions. If you’re going back to back with another interview, you asked to take a 5 minute break if you’d like one.
The next 50 or so minutes covers a combination of our Leadership Principle and Functional Competency questions.
With any time left, you’ll have the opportunity to ask the interviewer questions.
https://amazon.jobs/content/en/how-we-hire/interview-loop
https://amazon.jobs/content/en/how-we-hire/pm-t-interview-prep
Getting The Job:
Criteria #1. Raise our hiring bar for Senior Product Manager - Technical. All data points collected in your interview index to better than 50% of Senior PMTs already at Amazon.
A bar raising example is complex, large in scope, somewhat or highly ambiguous, and your decisions result in high impact for the business/ your customers.
Demonstrating high judgement can raise the bar. (Ie. When making product feature tradeoffs, you decisively advocate for what is best for customers, while simultaneously factoring in risk mitigation for your business.)
Criteria #2. Demonstrate you can grow within the role throughout your examples.
Interviewers look for an emergent pattern of being vocally self-critical.
This is covered by discussing your learnings. You can share them proactively or interviewers will frequently follow up asking what you learned from anecdotes you’ve shared throughout your interview (see STAR-LMethod below).
Interview Data Collection:
Interviewers will be typing the whole time and entering notes into a system where all other interviewers can read what they write.
The above tip means leadership principle data is supplemental. This means you do NOT have to guess the LP behind the question! If I ask you a “Customer Obsession” question and don’t get sufficient data, but another interviewer does while questioning another leadership principle, they will tag this in their notes and I can read about it later! All interviewers also discuss counter points during a robust debrief conversation.
Content Overview:
~80% of your interview will be responding to predictive behavioral questions rooted in our leadership principles. There are 16 Leadership principles in total. Only 12 will be covered in your virtual on-site (see competency list below).
~15% will be covering the Functional Competencies.
~5% will be asking the interviewers questions at the end of your interview. Good questions demonstrate that you’re already envisioning yourself within the position.
Interview Competency Focus Areas
Leadership Principles (LPs):
Customer Obsession
Learn and Be Curious
Earn Trust
Are Right, A Lot
Invent and Simplify
Ownership
Have Backbone; Disagree and Commit
Deliver Results
Insist on the Highest Standards
Think Big
Bias for Action
Dive Deep
Ex. Questions aligned to each LP:
Dealing with Ambiguity- Have you ever worked on a project / task whereby you have had minimal information and or minimal direction?
Are Right A Lot - Tell me about a time when you made a bad decision and the learning from the experience enabled you to make a good decision later.
Earns Trust - Give me an example of a tough or critical piece of feedback you received
Have Backbone -Tell me about a time that you strongly disagreed with your manager on something you deemed to be very important to the business.
Deliver Results - Tell me about a time where you not only met a goal but considerably exceeded expectations.
Customer Obsession - Can you give me an example of when you’ve been able to see around the corner to meet a customer need or
Insist on Highest Standards - Tell me about a time when you have been unsatisfied with the status quo.  What did you do to change it?  Were you successful?
Think Big - Tell me about time you were working on an initiative or goal and saw an opportunity to do something much bigger than the initial focus.
Bias for Action- Tell me about a time when you had to analyze facts quickly, define key issues, and respond immediately to a situation. What was the outcome?
Dive Deep - Tell me about a time you were trying to understand a problem on your team and you had to go down several layers to figure it out.  Who did you talk with and what information proved most valuable?  How did you use that information to help solve the problem?
Ownership - Tell me about a time when you took on something significant outside your area of responsibility
Invent and Simplify - Tell me about a time when you were able to make something simpler for customers. What drove you to implement this change? What was the impact?
Learn and Be Curious - What is the coolest thing you have learned on your own that has helped you better perform your job?
Functional:
PM Skills (Strategy/Vision & Product Roadmaps)
PM Tech Skills
Writing Sample
Deal with Ambiguity (not assigned to your interviews, but wanted to share prep just in case)
Interview Verbal and Written Communication Prep:
Do:
·         Be detail oriented in response. Stay connected to the customer/data in tradeoff explanations and decisions.
·         Check in with the interviewer, “Does that answer your question?” is a good way to keep the conversation flowing.
·         Answer questions directly. Think crisp, plain, business communication.
Do not:
·         Use jargon or buzzwords.
·         Stay too high level.
·         Overshare beyond the scope of a question [See STAR Method].
Best method to answer & common mistakes.
Leadership Principle (LP) questions will always target specific stories from your past. They often start with “Tell me about a time when….” Or “Give me an example of…”. For example, an LP question targeting Customer Obsession will go “Tell me about a time you received negative customer feedback.” What was it? What did you learn from this?”
STAR-L Method to answer.
S – Situation
Set the stage. Put the interviewer in your shoes. They’ve likely been at Amazon for years and it’s not obvious to them how your organization is structured or who your customers are. Not to mention yellow and red tape you need to navigate due to process and organizational constraints to product planning and execution.
Talk up complexity, scope, and ambiguity. This directly correlates with how “bar raising” your example is.
T – Task
Clearly explain what you were trying to accomplish.
A – Action
Delineate “I” vs “We. Interviewers are talking notes on you, and not your team. So please be sensitive when you say “I” or “We” when describing actions that occurred in relation to the task that you set out to accomplish. For example, “My team came up with the original idea to do X and I thought to add YZ because of the customer data…”.
R – Results
Quantifiable data – using numbers or metrics to communicate your results is often the most compelling and clear way to communicate how you/ your team performed in relation to a Task. Be ready to discuss any weaknesses of KPIs/metrics if prompted. I recommend having key figures prepared to reference within your interview. Please be careful not to read too much from pre-prepared notes.
Anecdotal evidence – It’s OK to not have numbers to share for every question you’re asked. For example, an Earn Trust question can be, “Tell me about a time you did not see eye to eye with a stakeholder.” Be prepared to share how you listened first, then influenced positive change based finding and moving towards common goal (ie. What’s best for the customer, data driven product roadmap, cost savings, etc.)
L – Learnings
Volunteering learnings and demonstrating the capacity of being vocally self-critical can satisfy hiring criteria #2.
A common follow up question is, “If you had to do it all over again, what would you have done differently?” More bluntly, candidates are frequently asked, “Did you learn anything from this?”
Feel free to share a learning or two if you feel it’s relevant. Maybe your team fell short of a goal or late to a deadline. Whatever you do, take ownership, be humble, and never point the finger at anyone else. I like to say, you’re either winning or you’re learning!
Functional:
PM Skills - This is usually a deep dive into a past product you’ve launched. Be ready to discuss product definition, prioritization, feature tradeoffs, and stakeholder management. Be connected to long term product strategy and how you’ve experimented and measured impact.
You will receive questions around your end to end product experience- so be prepared to talk about Internal tools used – who were your customers, what was the scope, how the scope changed, what is your impact to customers, revenue impact of the product; it’s Scalability - how you scaled the impact of your product to 1 to 2 to 20, how do you iterate?  Talk about roadmaps; your ability to deal with ambiguity.  How do you identify risks, how do you foresee an unknown risk or mitigate risk?  How do you influence other teams, how do you communicate with cross-functional teams, your stakeholders, leadership, how do you get your buy-in or earn trust from other teams?
Tech Skills - need to demonstrate you’re connected to the technical details and can drive the right customer outcomes through interactions with your technical stakeholders.
Common questions: “Tell me about the biggest technical challenge you’ve ever handled”. “Tell me about a time you pushed back on an engineering decision.” “Walk me through the technical design choices of a product you’ve launched.” Prepare to discuss how you balanced needs for internal customers and end users (external customers). Ideally you can explain a high level system design and how it affects customer behavior.
Understands the reasons behind product/feature architecture decisions (Q. Why did we build it this way? What business or technical assumptions were made? Do we need to build something else– if so why?).
Capable of holding an engineering team to a high standard for product solutions (similar to a technical manager). Recognize when technical design of a feature limits a product’s performance, ability to scale, and/or our ability innovate for customers in the future.
Able to discern which solutions require additional technical guidance (e.g., from senior engineers or subject matter experts).
Understands the impact a technical backlog has on the future of a product and the ability for development teams to execute. Knows how best to prioritize operational excellence work alongside feature delivery on a roadmap.
Able to assess emerging technologies and how to apply them to a product/feature use cases.
Additional considerations:
Dependency management
Pain points post launch?
Tech details of product in relation to the customer experience (latency, caching, scaling..)
Articulate tech tradeoffs and reason prioritization for customers.
Writing Sample
Attack one of two prompts. Both weighted the same. Make sure you address the entire prompt.
How you write is just as important as what you write.
1 - 1.5 pages is perfectly long enough. Don’t worry that the prompt asks for more.
Plain business language is perfect.
Make sure paragraphs flow well into each other.
Structure matters, the STAR method is a good framework to use.
Good sentence syntax and no typos.
Expect to be asked follow up questions by the hiring manager about what you write.
Use the strongest example you can.
DEALING WITH AMBIGUITY
Operates effectively in unstructured environment
Able to make decisions when all the information is not available
Drives toward problem resolution despite ambiguity or uncertainty
Understands how to get things done
Seeks clarity where necessary
Demonstrates flexibility
Drives forward initiatives
Ability to multi-task
Sample Ambiguity Questions
Have you ever worked in a job with a high level of ambiguity? (*Can you describe what that was like? Can you give me an example of how you handled the situation?)
What has been your experience in working with conflicting, delayed or ambiguous information? (*What did you do to make the most of the situation? )
Tell me about a time when you have needed to quickly change direction? What was the situation?
Have you ever worked on a project / task whereby you have had minimal information and or minimal direction? How did you manage the situation?
Tell me about a time when a decision was made or a course of action was taken that you did not agree with. (*How did it affect your planning? What were the other, better alternatives? Why weren’t they explored or implemented?)
Describe a time when you had a plan in place and circumstances changed requiring you to take a different approach. (*How did you adjust your plan to respond to the new requirements? What were the costs associated with making the change? How could the situation have been avoided?)
Miscellaneous Tips
You can use the same example up to two (2) times. If you use the same example again,  Interviewers will read about it anyway.
  call out you already used it!
Interviewers don’t comment on your responses. They’re trained to do this as to not bias the interview. We’re not robots. Don’t let this throw you off!

text:
## Creating Usage-Based Infrastructure for Proprietary Financial Data
During my tenure as Entrepreneur in Residence at Temasek's venture studio, working within a $400 billion sovereign wealth fund, I created the first marketplace that enabled AI developers to access proprietary financial data on a pay-per-query basis with embedded compliance tracking. This wasn't another data aggregator or API wrapper. It was infrastructure that solved both sides of a broken market: developers forced to purchase complete data catalogs at $500,000 annually when they only needed specific subsets, and publishers watching their content get consumed by AI without compensation or control.
The problem emerged through customer discovery with twenty-five AI development teams. Quantitative trading firms were purchasing entire data catalogs from traditional providers when they only needed specific segments, then dedicating 80% of engineering resources to preprocessing that data for AI consumption. Meanwhile, publishers watched AI companies scrape their paywalled content with no attribution or compensation. The traditional licensing model was designed for human analysts and fundamentally mismatched how AI systems actually consume data.
Temasek recruited me because they recognized that rights management principles from music could transform financial data monetization. Having built royalty payment systems at Warner Chappell Music that processed $2 billion in annual payments, I understood how to track, attribute, and compensate for granular usage at scale. The same infrastructure that enabled streaming services to pay artists fractions of pennies per stream could enable AI applications to pay data providers fractions of dollars per query.
The market had fragmented solutions but no integrated approach. Platforms offered usage-based pricing for public data only, semantic search for generic content, or publisher monetization without financial data partnerships. The critical gap was proprietary, paywalled financial content with embedded compliance. I recognized that solving proprietary licensing with compliance tracking would become critical infrastructure for how AI systems access regulated data in financial services.
I designed Kunik to operate as infrastructure, not just a product. Leading a four-person team, I built enough conviction in the vision that all four members committed to leaving the venture studio to join the independent company when we spun out. I orchestrated three parallel workstreams: securing data partnerships with established financial and business publishers, building technical systems that made heterogeneous data AI-ready, and creating unit economics that worked for both sides of the marketplace. The core innovation was recognizing that developers didn't need another search engine - they needed a compliance layer that made it safe to consume proprietary data programmatically. By embedding attribution, audit trails, and licensing enforcement directly into the API, I eliminated the six-month legal review that typically blocked AI teams from accessing premium content.
The most critical technical decision involved compliance architecture. My engineering lead advocated for asynchronous permission checking to optimize for sub-100ms response times. I mandated synchronous validation, adding 100 milliseconds to every request to check user permissions, data licenses, territorial restrictions, and audit requirements before returning results. The team argued this would hurt performance, but I held firm. For financial services customers, compliance isn't optional - it's existential. The audit trail I built reduced our enterprise compliance approval timeline from six months to thirty days, enabling faster sales cycles with regulated institutions.
The second critical decision involved our go-to-market strategy. The Temasek partners argued nobody would pay for data that was technically free through EDGAR and wanted to wait until we had multiple proprietary sources. I pushed back, explaining that developers weren't paying for the data itself but for the preprocessing, search capabilities, and unified access. Our quantitative fund design partner validated this. While they could get SEC filings through Bloomberg, they couldn't test specific datasets before purchasing entire catalogs. Starting with enriched public data would prove our infrastructure value while we built proprietary partnerships. During our two-month pilot, we processed 3,000 queries daily, with developers specifically citing the value of plug-and-play SEC access for backtesting.
For data providers, I created transparency and control. Publishers could see exactly how their content was being used, set granular permissions, and receive seventy percent of revenue generated from their content. They could finally monetize specialized financial content that was valuable for specific AI applications but didn't justify enterprise subscriptions.
Building custom data connectors saved $360,000 annually while giving us precise control over data quality. Implementing hybrid search solved the core problem where financial professionals needed both exact document matching and conceptual discovery.
The early validation exceeded expectations. We processed 3,000 test queries daily from design partners. The quantitative trading firm valued the ability to test datasets before committing and appreciated the unified API. An investor intelligence platform used our private market data integration to access information that previously required a $50,000 annual subscription. However, we encountered the classic two-sided marketplace challenge: developers wanted more proprietary sources before committing, while publishers wanted proven developer demand.
Seven months in, as we prepared to spin out from the venture studio, my co-founder and I faced a critical decision point. The entire team had committed to joining the spin-out and we had validated demand through our pilot. However, the market landscape was shifting. Anthropic had announced Model Context Protocol in November 2024, a standardized way to connect AI systems to data sources. While MCP didn't provide the compliance tracking I'd built, it would make accessing enriched public SEC data significantly easier. Our strategy had been to prove value with public data while building proprietary partnerships, but publishers still needed 12 to 18 months to develop frameworks for programmatic AI licensing. Combined with new leadership at the fund questioning our timeline, we recognized that our window for the wedge strategy was closing faster than the publisher market was developing. As we sat down to finalize equity agreements, we weren't aligned on the risk under these shifting conditions. Rather than force a founding partnership without clear stakeholder backing, we jointly decided to pause.
The core lesson was about infrastructure adoption timing and go-to-market sequencing. I underestimated how quickly standardized protocols like MCP would gain adoption. What I thought was an 18-month window compressed to 6 months. More critically, infrastructure plays serving regulated industries need an anchor sponsor: a major financial institution willing to adopt early and validate the model. Publishers required minimum revenue guarantees, which meant I needed committed buyer demand before I could secure supply. In retrospect, securing a tier-one financial institution as a launch partner who could commit to minimum spend would have unlocked publisher partnerships. The market has since validated the need. I've tracked three venture-backed teams building similar infrastructure, confirming the innovation was sound but the sequencing needed refinement.
