title: Amazon Interview

text:
## What I Built at Kunik - Eval Framework One-Sheet
  The Problem I Was Solving
  We had a RAG system serving financial data to developers. Early accuracy was 78% - meaning 1 in 5 queries returned bad results. For customers making trading decisions in regulated industries, that’s not good enough. I needed a way to measure quality systematically so we could improve.
  What a RAG System Actually Does (Two Steps)
  Step 1: Retrieval - User asks a question, system searches the database and pulls back relevant documents. This is finding the right information.
  Step 2: Generation - The retrieved documents get passed to an LLM (like Claude) which reads them and generates an answer. This is synthesizing the information.
  When something goes wrong, it’s either a retrieval problem (wrong docs, bad ranking) or a generation problem (LLM hallucinated or misunderstood good docs).
  What an Eval Harness Is
  A script that automates quality testing. Instead of manually reviewing every query, you run 50-100 queries at once, get a score, make a change, run again, see if the score improved.
  It has three parts: a test set (queries + expected answers), a runner (code that executes queries and captures outputs), and scoring logic (compares outputs to expected answers and calculates metrics).
  What I Spec’d (My Job as PM)
  The test queries - Real questions from customer interviews. “What’s the valuation of X?” “What are revenue trends for Y?” Categorized by public vs private markets.
  The expected answers (ground truth) - I researched and documented correct answers for each query. Verified against source data. This is where I became the domain expert.
  Scoring criteria - Defined what “correct” means. Is a partial answer acceptable? How recent does data need to be? What’s the tolerance for numerical accuracy? Documented these rules so scoring was consistent.
  Metadata to capture on failures - The query, expected answer, actual response, which documents were retrieved, ranking order, latency. This let me diagnose WHY something failed.
  Success threshold - “We need 90%+ accuracy before enterprise pilots.” Based on what regulated industry customers would accept.
  The Workflow
  Step 1: I created the test set - queries and correct answers in a spreadsheet.
  Step 2: Engineer ran the harness - script loops through queries, hits RAG system, captures responses, compares to expected.
  Step 3: I got a failure report - 78% accuracy, here are the 11 that failed with metadata.
  Step 4: I analyzed failures - looked at each one, tagged it as retrieval problem, ranking problem, or generation problem.
  Step 5: I prioritized for engineering - “7 of these are ranking issues, 3 are retrieval misses, 1 is hallucination. Ranking is highest priority.”
  Step 6: Engineering fixed, we re-ran - they adjusted hybrid search weighting, re-ran harness, accuracy improved to 85%. Repeat until target.
  How I Diagnosed Failures
  Retrieval problem: Wrong documents came back entirely. Asked about Tesla stock, got Tesla Energy. Fix is on the search side.
  Ranking problem: Right documents exist but ranked too low. Answer was result #47 instead of #1, or surfaced 2023 data when 2024 exists. Fix is tuning the hybrid search balance.
  Generation problem: Right documents retrieved but LLM misinterpreted. Hallucinated, pulled wrong number from table, or gave generic response instead of answering. Fix is on the prompt side.
  Most of our issues were ranking - we had trustworthy sources (connected to publisher APIs) but weren’t surfacing the most relevant/recent data first.
  Hybrid Search (Why It Matters)
  We balanced two search methods:
  Semantic search - Finds conceptually similar content. Good for understanding intent. “Tesla valuation” might match “TSLA market cap” even though words are different.
  Keyword search (BM25) - Finds exact matches. Good for specific terms like company names, ticker symbols, dates.
  If keyword weighted too heavily, you miss conceptual matches. If semantic weighted too heavily, results are vague. We tuned this balance based on eval results.
  The Feedback Loop
  When customers flagged bad responses in production, we’d add that query to the test set. Now the harness tests for that case going forward. Every real-world failure becomes training data for the next iteration.
  Metrics I Used
  Precision - Of the results returned, how many were actually relevant?
  Recall - Of all relevant results that exist, how many did we find?
  Latency - How fast is the response?
  Accuracy - Overall pass rate on the test set.
  The Result
  Went from 78% to 96% accuracy. But more importantly, we had a repeatable system - every bad response became data for the next version. That’s what makes evaluation systems actually work.
  Key Insight
  “I’d start with eval harnesses FIRST, not architecture. Understanding how to measure quality is more important than understanding how systems work. Once you know how to evaluate, you can test different approaches empirically instead of debating architecturally.”

## Retrieval vs Generation - what's the difference
  Think of your RAG system as a two-step process:
  Step 1: Retrieval
  The user asks a question. The system searches your database to find relevant documents or chunks of data. This is the "R" in RAG - Retrieval.
  At Kunik, you had financial data from publishers. When someone asked "what's the valuation of Tesla," the retrieval step would search across your connected data sources and pull back chunks that might contain the answer.
  Retrieval problems look like:
  Wrong documents came back (you asked about Tesla stock, got Tesla Energy)
  Right documents exist but weren't found (the answer is in your database but search missed it)
  Right documents found but ranked too low (answer was result #47 instead of result #1)
  Step 2: Generation
  Once you have the retrieved documents, you pass them to an LLM (like Claude) with a prompt that says something like: "Based on this context, answer the user's question."
  The LLM reads the retrieved chunks and generates an answer.
  Generation problems look like:
  LLM hallucinated (made up information that wasn't in the context)
  LLM misunderstood the data (pulled the wrong number from a table)
  LLM gave a confident answer when it should have said "I don't know"
  LLM summarized poorly (lost important nuance)
  Why this matters for debugging
  When your eval harness flagged a wrong answer, you had to figure out which step broke.
  If it was retrieval: The LLM never had a chance. You gave it bad inputs, so it gave bad outputs. The fix is on the search side - adjusting embeddings, tuning hybrid search weighting, improving chunking.
  If it was generation: The LLM had good inputs but still produced bad outputs. The fix is on the prompt side - better instructions, clearer formatting, maybe few-shot examples.
  What you did vs what engineering did
  Here's how the handoff worked based on what you told me:
  Your job as PM:
  Define what "wrong" means (you verified answers, became the domain expert)
  Identify patterns in failures (are we seeing mostly retrieval problems or generation problems?)
  Prioritize which failures matter most (a wrong valuation number is worse than a slightly outdated date)
  Bring findings to engineering with evidence ("these 15 queries failed, and 12 of them look like ranking issues")
  Engineering's job:
  Diagnose the technical root cause (why is the ranking off? is it the BM25 weighting? the embedding model?)
  Implement the fix (adjust parameters, change the chunking strategy, modify the prompt)
  Re-run the eval to validate
  You weren't writing the fix. But you were the one who figured out what was broken and why it mattered. Engineering couldn't prioritize without you telling them which failures hurt customers most.
  On your ranking point
  You said accuracy wasn't always the issue - it was more about ranking. That's a retrieval problem, and it's actually a sophisticated insight.
  Your sources were trustworthy (connected directly to publisher APIs). So the data itself was good. But if the system ranked an outdated document higher than a recent one, or surfaced a less relevant chunk before a more relevant one, the answer would be wrong even though the right data existed.
  This is why you tuned hybrid search. You were balancing:
  Semantic search (finds conceptually similar content, good for understanding intent)
  Keyword search / BM25 (finds exact matches, good for specific terms like company names or dates)
  If keyword search was weighted too heavily, you'd miss conceptual matches. If semantic search was weighted too heavily, you'd get vague results that weren't specific enough.
  What you should know for tomorrow
  You don't need to explain the math behind BM25 or how embeddings work. But you should be able to say:
  "When we found wrong answers, I'd first figure out if it was a retrieval problem or a generation problem. If the right data wasn't being surfaced - or was ranked too low - that's retrieval. If the right data was there but the LLM misinterpreted it, that's generation. Most of our issues were retrieval - specifically ranking. We'd tune the hybrid search balance and re-run evals to see if scores improved."
  Does this click now? Any part still fuzzy?

text:
## What Zoom is actually hiring you to do
  Ram runs the Zoom Virtual Agent team. A Virtual Agent is basically a chatbot that handles customer support - someone types "how do I reset my password" and the AI tries to resolve it without escalating to a human.
  The problem with these systems is: how do you know if they're actually good? A customer might get an answer, but was it the right answer? Was the tone appropriate? Did they actually solve their problem or did they just give up?
  That's what this role is about. You're building the systems that measure and improve the quality of AI conversations at scale. Not just dashboards - the actual engine that evaluates whether the Virtual Agent is doing its job.
  What an evaluation framework actually is
  Think of it like this: you have an AI system producing outputs. Those outputs could be good or bad. An evaluation framework is the system you build to programmatically assess quality so you can improve over time.
  It has three core components:
  1. Ground truth (what "good" looks like)
  You need labeled examples. At Kunik, you had 1,200 query-response pairs that were scored by domain experts. Someone looked at a query, looked at the response, and said "this is correct" or "this is wrong" or "this is partially correct."
  Without this, you're flying blind. You can't measure accuracy if you don't know what the right answer is.
  Question for you: At Kunik, who did the labeling? How did you decide what criteria to score on?
  2. Metrics (how you quantify quality)
  You need numbers that tell you if things are getting better or worse. At Kunik you used:
  Precision - of the results returned, how many were actually relevant?
  Recall - of all the relevant results that exist, how many did we find?
  Latency - how fast is the response?
  Cost per query - how much does each request cost us?
  For Zoom's Virtual Agent, the metrics would be different. They care about things like:
  Containment rate - did the Virtual Agent resolve the issue without escalating to a human?
  First contact resolution (FCR) - was the problem solved on the first try?
  CSAT - did the customer rate the interaction positively?
  Average handle time (AHT) - how long did it take?
  Question for you: Why did you pick precision and recall specifically? What were you trying to optimize for?
  3. Feedback loops (how the system improves)
  This is the part most people miss. An evaluation framework isn't a one-time thing - it's a system that continuously improves the AI.
  At Kunik, when a customer flagged a bad response, that feedback went back into your labeled dataset. Now you have a new example of what "bad" looks like. You can retrain, retune, or adjust based on real user signals.
  Question for you: Walk me through exactly how that feedback loop worked. Customer flags something - then what happens?
  How you worked with engineering
  You weren't writing the code. But you were the one who figured out where failures were happening.
  The Kunik system had a pipeline:
  Query comes in
  Retrieval - the system searches for relevant documents (this is where hybrid search happens - combining semantic/vector search with keyword/BM25 search)
  Chunking - the retrieved documents get broken into pieces
  LLM synthesis - Claude or GPT takes the chunks and generates a response
  When accuracy was 78%, you didn't know which step was broken. The evaluation framework helped you isolate it. You'd look at failed queries and trace them through the pipeline:
  Did we retrieve the right documents? (retrieval problem)
  Did we chunk them correctly? (chunking problem)
  Did the LLM synthesize a good answer from good inputs? (generation problem)
  You found most failures were in the hybrid search layer - the balance between semantic and keyword search was off. You brought that finding to engineering, showed them which queries were failing and why, and they adjusted the weighting.
  Question for you: Can you explain what hybrid search is in your own words? Why do you need both semantic and keyword search?
  What Ram is going to want to hear tomorrow
  He's not going to quiz you on technical definitions. He wants to know:
  Have you actually built evaluation systems, or did you just manage people who did?
  Do you understand why this is hard?
  Can you think through the problem from first principles?
  The hardest part of evaluation isn't the math - it's defining what "good" means. For a Virtual Agent, is a partial answer acceptable? What if the customer got their answer but the tone was robotic? What if the AI was accurate but the customer still escalated because they wanted to talk to a human?
  These are judgment calls. You have to make them, document them, and be consistent. That's what makes evaluation systems actually work.
  Now - answer my questions above so we can make sure you actually understand this, not just have answers memorized.

text:
## Eval notes
  Technical Understanding: How to Think About Evaluation
  "How would you approach building an evaluation framework for conversational AI?"
  Start from the customer problem and work backwards.
  First question you ask yourself: What does "good" look like for this product? For a Virtual Agent, "good" probably means the customer got their issue resolved, didn't have to escalate, and didn't hate the experience. That's your north star.
  Second question: How do I measure that? You can't just ask "was this conversation good?" - that's too vague. You break it down into components you can actually measure. Did the AI understand the question? Did it retrieve relevant information? Did it generate an appropriate response? Did the customer's behavior indicate success (they stopped asking, they didn't escalate, they rated it well)?
  Third question: What's my ground truth? For factual answers, you can verify against documentation - "how do I share my screen" has a correct answer. For subjective things like tone, you need rubrics - criteria that humans can score consistently.
  Fourth question: How do I make this repeatable? You're not manually reviewing every conversation. You need automation - a harness that can run thousands of test cases, score them, surface failures, and let you track improvement over time.
  Fifth question: How does this connect to real customer outcomes? Your eval metrics need to correlate with business metrics. If your eval says quality is 95% but customers are still escalating at the same rate, your eval is measuring the wrong thing.
  That's the thinking process. Start with what "good" means, break it into measurable components, define ground truth, automate it, and validate against real outcomes.
  "What metrics would you prioritize for a Virtual Agent?"
  Think about what a Virtual Agent is trying to do. Its job is to resolve customer issues without human intervention. So you're measuring: did it work, how well did it work, and what was the experience like.
  Did it work? That's containment rate - the percentage of conversations where the AI resolved the issue without escalating to a human. This is the core metric. If containment is low, the AI isn't doing its job.
  How well did it work? That's first contact resolution - did the customer have to come back with the same issue? High containment but low FCR means the AI is giving answers that seem right but don't actually solve the problem. The customer leaves, tries the solution, it doesn't work, they come back.
  What was the experience like? That's CSAT (customer satisfaction) - did they rate the interaction positively? And AHT (average handle time) - how long did it take? Fast and wrong is bad. Slow and right might also be bad if customers get frustrated waiting.
  Where does it break? Deflection rate tells you at what point customers give up and ask for a human. If they bail after the first message, maybe the AI didn't understand the question. If they bail after three exchanges, maybe the AI understood but couldn't help.
  When someone asks you to prioritize, think about what matters most to the business. Containment is probably first - that's the whole point of a Virtual Agent. Then CSAT - containment doesn't matter if customers hate the experience. Then the diagnostic metrics like FCR and deflection that help you understand where to improve.
  "How do you evaluate something subjective like tone?"
  This is harder than accuracy because there's no single "right answer." But you can still make it systematic.
  First, define what you're evaluating. "Tone" is vague. Break it into specific things you can observe: Was the response empathetic? Was it professional? Was it clear? Was it appropriately confident (not hedging too much, not overconfident)?
  Second, create a rubric. For each dimension, describe what "good" and "bad" look like. Empathetic might mean: acknowledges the customer's frustration, uses phrases like "I understand" or "I'm sorry you're experiencing this." Not empathetic might mean: jumps straight to the solution without acknowledging the problem, sounds robotic or dismissive.
  Third, calibrate with humans. Have multiple people score the same conversations using your rubric. If they disagree a lot, your rubric isn't clear enough. Refine until you get consistency.
  Fourth, consider using LLMs to scale. Once you have a calibrated rubric, you can prompt an LLM to score conversations using the same criteria. It won't be perfect, but it lets you evaluate thousands of conversations instead of dozens. You validate the LLM scoring against human scoring to make sure it's reliable.
  Fifth, connect to outcomes. Ultimately, you want to know if tone affects customer satisfaction. Do conversations scored as "low empathy" correlate with lower CSAT? If not, maybe tone doesn't matter as much as you thought - or your rubric isn't capturing what actually matters to customers.
  "What's the difference between offline and online evaluation?"
  Think of it like rehearsal vs live performance.
  Offline evaluation is running tests before you deploy. You have a test set with known scenarios, you run them through the system, you measure performance. This is what you did at Kunik - 1,200 queries with expected answers, run the harness, see what passes. It's controlled, repeatable, and lets you catch problems before customers see them.
  The limitation: your test set might not cover everything real users do. Customers ask weird questions, misspell things, have context you didn't anticipate. Offline eval tells you the system works on cases you thought of.
  Online evaluation is measuring in production with real users. A/B tests, live metrics, actual customer behavior. This tells you how the system performs in the real world, not just in controlled tests.
  The limitation: you can't experiment freely without risking customer experience. And you need enough traffic to get statistical significance.
  You need both. Offline eval is your gate before shipping - nothing goes to production unless it passes your test suite. Online eval is your feedback loop after shipping - are real customers actually having a better experience?
  When you make a change, the flow is: run offline eval to make sure you didn't break anything, deploy to a small percentage of users, measure online metrics, if they look good, roll out wider.
  Process and Collaboration: How to Work With Engineering
  "How do you work with engineering on ambiguous problems?"
  The key is knowing what you own vs what they own.
  You own the "what" and "why" - what problem are we solving, why does it matter, how do we know if we've solved it. You define success criteria, you prioritize which failures matter most, you bring the customer perspective.
  They own the "how" - how do we technically implement this, what architecture, what algorithms, what trade-offs between approaches.
  The overlap is where collaboration happens. You might say "we need to improve ranking so recent documents surface first." That's a requirement. They might come back with three options: weight by date, use a decay function, or add recency as a retrieval signal. They explain trade-offs. You ask questions: "Which one is fastest to implement? Which one gives us the most control to tune later?" You decide together based on priorities.
  When things are ambiguous - and in AI they often are - you use experiments to resolve it. Instead of debating whether approach A or B is better, you say "let's test both and see what the eval says." Data beats opinions.
  The worst thing you can do is either: (a) tell engineering exactly how to build it when you don't have the technical depth, or (b) just say "make it better" and give them no direction. You need to be specific about the problem and success criteria, but leave room for them to figure out the solution.
  "How do you prioritize what to fix?"
  Start with customer impact, not frequency.
  A failure that happens 100 times a day but barely bothers customers is lower priority than a failure that happens 10 times a day but makes customers furious or causes them real harm.
  Think about severity. For a Virtual Agent: giving the wrong answer to a billing question could cost someone money - high severity. Sounding slightly robotic but giving the right answer - low severity. Not understanding a question and asking for clarification - medium severity, depends on how often it happens.
  Think about volume. All else equal, fix things that affect more customers first.
  Think about effort. If two problems have similar impact but one is a quick fix and one is a major architecture change, do the quick fix first. Ship improvements incrementally.
  Think about dependencies. Some fixes unlock other fixes. If your retrieval is fundamentally broken, there's no point fine-tuning generation prompts - you're polishing garbage. Fix retrieval first.
  When you bring priorities to engineering, be explicit about your reasoning. Don't just say "fix these 10 things in this order." Say "I ranked these by customer impact. The top 3 are billing-related failures because they cost customers money. The next 4 are high-volume issues affecting thousands of conversations. The last 3 are edge cases we should track but aren't urgent."
  "How do you handle disagreements about what 'good' looks like?"
  This is one of the hardest parts of evaluation. Two smart people can look at the same AI response and disagree about whether it's good.
  First, get explicit about what you're disagreeing on. Is it factual accuracy? Completeness? Tone? Different people prioritize different things. Name the dimension.
  Second, look at examples together. Pull 10 responses you disagree on. Go through each one and articulate why you think it's good or bad. Often you'll find you're applying different criteria, and making the criteria explicit resolves the disagreement.
  Third, write it down. Create a rubric that documents the criteria. "A good response must include X, Y, and Z. Partial credit if it has X and Y but not Z. Fail if it's missing X." Now you're not debating vibes, you're debating whether the rubric makes sense.
  Fourth, test against customer outcomes. If you still disagree about the rubric, look at real data. Do responses that score high on your criteria correlate with higher customer satisfaction? If your rubric says something is great but customers hate it, your rubric is wrong.
  The goal isn't to "win" the disagreement. The goal is to build a shared understanding of quality that you can measure consistently.
  Situational: How to Handle Real-World Problems
  "You discover accuracy dropped 5% after a model update. What do you do?"
  Don't panic, and don't guess. Diagnose systematically.
  Step one: Confirm it's real. Is this a measurement issue or a real regression? Did something change in how you're calculating accuracy? Did your test set change? Rule out false alarms.
  Step two: Isolate the change. What exactly was updated? Was it the retrieval model, the generation model, the prompts, the underlying data? You need to know what variable changed.
  Step three: Run your eval suite and compare before/after. Don't just look at the overall number - look at the breakdown. Which query types regressed? Maybe accuracy dropped 5% overall but it's because one category went from 90% to 60% while everything else stayed flat. That tells you where to focus.
  Step four: Diagnose the failures. Look at the specific queries that used to pass and now fail. What changed in the output? Is it a retrieval problem (different documents coming back) or a generation problem (same documents, different response)?
  Step five: Decide whether to roll back or fix forward. If the regression is severe and affecting customers now, roll back to the previous version while you investigate. If it's minor or you can fix it quickly, push a fix.
  Step six: Add the failing cases to your test suite so this doesn't happen again. The regression happened because your eval didn't catch it - strengthen your eval.
  "A customer complains the AI gave a wrong answer. How do you investigate?"
  Treat it like debugging. Trace through the system step by step.
  Step one: Get the specific conversation. Not a summary, the actual logs - what the customer said, what the AI responded, any intermediate steps.
  Step two: Reproduce if you can. Take the customer's query and run it through your system now. Do you get the same bad answer? If so, the problem is still there. If you get a correct answer now, something might have changed, or there might be inconsistency in the system.
  Step three: Trace the pipeline. What documents were retrieved? Were they relevant? If bad documents were retrieved, it's a retrieval problem - figure out why search returned the wrong results. If good documents were retrieved but the answer was still wrong, it's a generation problem - the LLM misinterpreted or hallucinated.
  Step four: Determine root cause. Why did this happen? Is it a gap in your data? A limitation of the search algorithm? A prompt that doesn't handle this case well? An edge case the model wasn't trained on?
  Step five: Fix it and verify. Implement a fix, run your eval to make sure you didn't break anything else, confirm the specific failing case now passes.
  Step six: Add it to your test set. This customer surfaced a case you weren't testing for. Now you are. That's the feedback loop.
  "How would you measure if a new feature actually improved the experience?"
  You need a controlled experiment, not just before/after comparison.
  The problem with before/after: lots of things change over time - customer mix, seasonality, other features shipping. If you launch a feature and metrics go up, you can't be sure the feature caused it.
  The solution: A/B test. Split users into two groups randomly. Group A gets the new feature, Group B doesn't. Compare metrics between groups. If Group A does better, the feature caused it.
  What metrics to compare depends on what the feature is supposed to do. If you're improving answer accuracy, look at containment rate - does Group A escalate less? Look at CSAT - does Group A rate conversations higher? Look at FCR - does Group A come back with the same issue less often?
  Watch for statistical significance. If Group A has 80.1% containment and Group B has 80.0%, that's probably noise, not a real improvement. You need enough data to be confident the difference is real.
  Watch for unintended consequences. Maybe your feature improves accuracy but tanks latency - customers get better answers but have to wait longer. You need to look at multiple metrics, not just the one you're optimizing for.
  Watch for segment differences. Maybe the feature helps one type of customer but hurts another. Break down results by user segment to see if the improvement is universal or localized.
  The Meta-Skill: Thinking From First Principles
  Across all of these situations, the pattern is the same:
  Start with the customer problem. What are we trying to achieve? What does success look like?
  Break it down into measurable components. Don't try to measure vague things like "quality." Define specific dimensions you can observe.
  Use data to resolve ambiguity. When you're not sure which approach is better, test both. When you disagree with someone, look at evidence together.
  Close the loop. Whatever you learn should feed back into your system - new test cases, refined metrics, updated rubrics.
  That's what a PM who owns AI quality does. You're not writing code. You're defining what good looks like, building systems to measure it, and using data to continuously improve.
  Does this help you understand the thinking, not just the answers? Any of these situations you want to go deeper on?

text:
## ONE-PAGER (WITH ZOOM CONNECTIONS)
  Part 10: When You Need an Evaluation System
  Part 11: Defining What "Correct" Means — The Rubric
  Part 12: Building the Test Set — Ground Truth
  Part 13: Running Evaluation and Measuring
  Part 14: Diagnosing Failures
  Part 15: Implementing Fixes
  Part 16: Validating Improvements
  Part 17: Data Schema for Evaluation
  Part 18: Calibration — LLM as Judge
  Part 19: Ongoing Monitoring
title: Zoom Prep

text:
## How do you measure precision and recall at scale with millions of conversations?"
  "You can't manually review millions of conversations. So you use an LLM-as-judge.
  You define a rubric—what does accurate mean, what does relevant mean, what does good tone mean. Then you prompt the LLM: 'Here's the conversation, here's the rubric, score each dimension 1-3 and explain why.'
  But you can't just trust the LLM blindly. You calibrate it. You take 100-200 conversations, have humans score them, then run the LLM on the same set. You measure alignment—does the LLM agree with humans 85% or more? If not, you analyze the disagreements, adjust the prompts, and iterate until you hit that threshold.
  Once calibrated, you run the LLM-as-judge on all conversations at scale. Then you aggregate: what percentage scored 3 on accuracy, what percentage scored 2, what percentage scored 1. You can slice by topic, by channel, by customer.
  The LLM scores are proxies. You validate them against real outcomes. If conversations that score high on quality also have lower repeat contact and higher CSAT, your evaluation is measuring something real. If not, your rubric is wrong and you go back to square one."
title: more questions

text:
## "How would you build an evaluation system from scratch?"
  "I'd start by defining what quality means for a Virtual Agent. It's not one thing—a conversation can be accurate but have bad tone, or have great tone but not resolve the issue. So I'd identify the dimensions that matter: accuracy, relevance, tone, and resolution.
  For each dimension, I'd build a rubric. Pull 50-100 sample conversations, sort into piles—clearly good, clearly bad, somewhere in the middle. Examine what makes the good ones good. Write scoring criteria with specific examples. Test with multiple raters until we hit 85% agreement.
  Then I'd create a test set—maybe 200 conversations across different topics, channels, and outcomes. Have humans score them to create ground truth.
  Then I'd work with data science to implement the LLM-as-judge. They translate my rubrics into prompts. We run the LLM against the ground truth and calibrate—measure alignment, analyze disagreements, adjust prompts, iterate until we hit 85%.
  After deployment, I'd set up ongoing monitoring. Weekly sample checks, monthly alignment tracking. And I'd connect evaluation scores to business outcomes—if accuracy scores are high but repeat contact is also high, something's wrong with the evaluation."
title: more questions

text:
## "What metrics would you put on the customer dashboard?"
  "I'd organize in layers based on who's looking.
  Executive layer: outcome metrics only. Containment rate, CSAT, trends over time, benchmark comparisons. One screen, 30 seconds, red/yellow/green. They want to know: is this working?
  Operations layer: outcomes plus diagnostics by topic. 'Containment is 68% overall, but billing is 54% while password resets are 91%.' They want to know: where should I focus?
  Technical layer: all three—outcomes, diagnostics, and system health. Accuracy scores, intent recognition rates, retrieval relevance, transcription accuracy for voice. Drill-down to specific conversations. They want to know: what's technically broken?
  The dashboard should let users move between layers. An executive sees containment is down, clicks to see it's billing, clicks again to see retrieval relevance dropped for billing. They can drill as deep as they want."
title: more questions

text:
## "How would you measure first contact resolution for unauthenticated voice callers?"
  "FCR means the customer's issue got solved in one interaction without calling back. To measure it, I need to link calls from the same person about the same issue.
  For unauthenticated voice, I'd use probabilistic identity matching. Phone number is the primary signal—if the same number calls back within 48 hours, likely the same person. I'd supplement with conversation topic matching—if both calls are about 'refund for order #12345,' that strengthens the link.
  FCR would be: total calls minus repeat contacts, divided by total calls. If we had 1,000 calls and 200 were followed by a repeat contact from the same number about the same topic within 48 hours, FCR is 80%.
  It's not perfect. People use different phones, caller ID can be blocked. But it gives a directionally accurate measure I can track over time. If FCR trends down, resolution quality is degrading, even if the absolute number isn't perfectly accurate."
title: more questions

text:
## "What's the relationship between traditional contact center metrics and AI evaluation metrics?"
  "Traditional metrics tell you WHAT happened. AI metrics tell you WHY.
  Traditional metrics like containment, CSAT, and FCR measure business outcomes. They've existed for decades. They tell you: are we saving money? Are customers happy?
  AI metrics like accuracy, intent recognition, retrieval relevance, transcription accuracy measure the AI system itself. They're diagnostic. When containment drops, AI metrics tell you which pipeline stage is failing.
  You need both. If I only have traditional metrics, I know something is broken but not what to fix. If I only have AI metrics, I might optimize technical scores that don't connect to customer outcomes.
  The flow is: traditional metrics identify WHERE the problem is—containment dropped for billing questions. AI metrics diagnose WHY—retrieval relevance dropped for billing topics. Now I know what to fix."
title: more questions

text:
## "Containment is high but customers are complaining. What's going on?"
  "High containment means conversations aren't escalating to humans. But containment doesn't mean the customer was actually helped. They might have hung up frustrated, gotten a wrong answer they didn't realize was wrong, or given up.
  I'd look at repeat contact rate. If containment is 72% but repeat contact is 35%, a third of customers are calling back. The bot is 'containing' calls by giving answers, but those answers aren't solving problems.
  I'd dig into which topics have high repeat contact. Maybe claims status inquiries have 45% repeat contact. I'd pull sample conversations. Maybe the bot is giving accurate status—'your claim is in review'—but not giving customers what they actually want: 'When will I hear back? What's the next step?'
  The bot is technically accurate but not helpful. It's answering the literal question without addressing the underlying need. The fix is updating the bot's responses to include next steps and timelines, not just status."
title: more questions

text:
## "How do you handle it when a customer says your evaluation scores are wrong?"
  "I take it seriously. If customers don't trust the evaluation, they don't trust the product.
  I ask for the specific conversations they think are scored wrong. I pull them and review myself, comparing the bot's responses to source documents.
  Usually I find a mix. Some are real evaluation failures—I investigate why. Some the customer misunderstood what we're measuring. Some are genuinely ambiguous.
  For real failures, I dig into root causes. Maybe retrieval pulled wrong articles and the LLM-as-judge only saw wrong articles, so it scored 'accurate' against bad information. Maybe incomplete answers were scored as accurate because the rubric didn't distinguish completeness.
  For each root cause, I identify a fix. Add retrieval relevance as a separate check. Update the rubric to distinguish complete from incomplete.
  Then I communicate back to the customer. Acknowledge their concern was valid, explain what I found, share the fixes. They feel heard and understand the nuance."
title: more questions

text:
## "Voice accuracy is lower than chat. Why?"
  "Voice has two additional pipeline stages: transcription at the start and speech synthesis at the end. That's where I'd focus.
  I'd sample voice failures and trace through the pipeline: transcription, intent recognition, retrieval, generation, synthesis. For each failure, which stage broke?
  Maybe I find 31% are transcription errors—the system misheard the customer. I'd dig deeper: what's causing them? Background noise, accents, speaking too fast, technical jargon, audio quality?
  If accents are the biggest category, I'd propose mitigations. When transcription confidence is low, have the bot ask for clarification. Build custom vocabulary for each customer's product names. Add transcription accuracy as a voice-specific metric on the dashboard so customers can see it.
  I'd also add voice-specific evaluation dimensions—transcription accuracy, speech clarity, pacing—so customers can diagnose voice-specific issues separately from overall quality."
title: more questions

text:
## Metal models 
  Here are all your mental models in one place. Save this for reference.
  MENTAL MODEL 1: THE DIAGNOSTIC FUNNEL
  MENTAL MODEL 2: THE RUBRIC DEVELOPMENT CYCLE
  MENTAL MODEL 3: THE CALIBRATION PROCESS
  MENTAL MODEL 4: THE SCHEMA QUESTION
  MENTAL MODEL 5: THE STAKEHOLDER PYRAMID
  Use when: Deciding what to show in the dashboard and how to organize it.
  Executive Layer (Top) → Operations Layer (Middle) → Technical Layer (Bottom)
  Top Layer: Executive View. Who: VP, C-level. What they ask: "Is this working? Should we invest more?" What they see: Outcome metrics only. Containment rate, CSAT, trends over time, comparison to benchmarks. What they don't need: Diagnostic details. How often: Monthly or quarterly. Design: One screen, 30-second glance, big numbers, trend arrows, red/yellow/green.
  Middle Layer: Operations View. Who: Operations managers, team leads. What they ask: "What's working, what's broken, where should we focus?" What they see: Outcome metrics PLUS diagnostics broken down by topic, channel, time period. "Containment is 68% overall, but billing is 54% while password resets are 91%." What they don't need: Deep system-level metrics. How often: Weekly, sometimes daily. Design: Summary at top, ability to break down, highlight problem areas.
  Bottom Layer: Technical View. Who: Product managers, engineering, data science. What they ask: "What's technically broken and how do we fix it?" What they see: All three layers. Outcomes, diagnostics, and system health. Transcription accuracy, intent recognition rates, retrieval relevance, latency, confidence distributions, drill-down to specific conversations. How often: Continuously when debugging, weekly for monitoring.
  How Information Flows: Up the pyramid: Information gets aggregated. Down the pyramid: Information gets detailed. The dashboard should enable movement in both directions.
  MENTAL MODEL 6: THE QUALITY LOOP
  Use when: Thinking about how the evaluation system drives continuous improvement.
  Measure → Surface → Diagnose → Fix → Measure Again
  Step 1: Measure. The evaluation system scores every conversation on multiple dimensions. These scores are the raw measurement of quality. This happens automatically, at scale, continuously.
  Step 2: Surface. Raw scores aren't useful until they're surfaced in a way people can act on. The dashboard aggregates scores into metrics, highlights problem areas, shows trends. Surfacing means making the data visible, understandable, and actionable.
  Step 3: Diagnose. Once a problem is surfaced, someone investigates. Using the Diagnostic Funnel, they segment the data, form hypotheses, and validate with specific examples. Diagnosis ends with a root cause.
  Step 4: Fix. Once you know the root cause, you implement a fix. Engineering fixes a bug. A customer updates their knowledge base. You adjust retrieval configuration. You update the rubric. The fix is specific and has an owner.
  Step 5: Measure Again. After the fix is deployed, you measure again. Did accuracy go back up? Did the specific failure pattern stop? If yes, move to the next problem. If no, go back to Step 3.
  Why This Is a Loop: It never ends because the product changes, customer behavior changes, the world changes, new problems emerge as you fix old ones. Quality is not a destination. It's a continuous process.
  MENTAL MODEL 7: PRIORITIZATION
  Use when: You have multiple things competing for attention and need to decide what to work on first.
  Filter by Urgency → Score Impact → Score Effort → Use the Matrix → Communicate
  Step 1: Filter by Urgency. Some things can't wait. Major customer threatening to churn. Critical bug causing data loss. CEO needs something for board meeting tomorrow. Urgent items get handled first. But ask: what happens if this waits one week? If nothing catastrophic, it's not truly urgent.
  Step 2: Score Impact. For non-urgent items, estimate impact. How many customers does this affect? How much does it affect them? Does it affect revenue, retention, or strategic goals? Does it unblock other important work? High/Medium/Low.
  Step 3: Score Effort. Estimate how much work. Multiple sprints and cross-team coordination? One sprint, straightforward? A few days? High/Medium/Low. Talk to engineering and data science if unsure.
  Step 4: Use the Matrix. High impact + Low effort: Do first (quick wins). High impact + High effort: Do second, plan carefully (big bets). Low impact + Low effort: Do if spare capacity (filler). Low impact + High effort: Don't do (traps).
  Step 5: Communicate. Once prioritized, communicate the decision and reasoning. Stakeholders who asked for deprioritized items need to understand why. "We're prioritizing X over Y because X affects 80% of customers while Y affects 10%, and X is less effort."
  The Key Insight: Prioritization isn't just about picking what's most important. It's about making tradeoffs explicit and defensible.
  MENTAL MODEL 8: TRADEOFFS
  Use when: You face a decision where optimizing for one thing means sacrificing another.
  Name Both Sides → Who Bears the Cost → What's Reversible → What Will You Learn → Decide and Own It
  Step 1: Name Both Sides. "We could launch now with 80% accuracy or wait two weeks for 90%." Option A (launch now): Gain speed, start learning. Lose quality, risk trust. Option B (wait): Gain quality, reduce risk. Lose time, delay learning.
  Step 2: Ask Who Bears the Cost. If you launch at 80%, customers bear the cost. If you wait, the business bears the cost. This matters for how you decide.
  Step 3: Ask What's Reversible. If you launch and it's bad, can you quickly improve? Or will customers churn and never come back? Irreversible decisions deserve more caution. Reversible decisions can be made faster.
  Step 4: Ask What You'll Learn. Sometimes one option gives you information the other doesn't. Launching lets you see real usage. Waiting means you might optimize the wrong things. If learning is valuable and downside is recoverable, bias toward action.
  Step 5: Make the Call and Own It. Don't waffle. State the decision and reasoning. "We're launching at 80% because the deadline is real, downside is recoverable, and we'll learn more from real usage. We commit to 90% within four weeks."
  The Key Insight: Tradeoffs aren't about finding the "right" answer. Your job is to make the tradeoff explicit, consider context, and make a defensible decision.
  MENTAL MODEL 9: WORKING WITH ENGINEERING AND DATA SCIENCE
  Use when: You need to partner with technical teams to get something built.
  Understand Ownership → Bring Problems Not Solutions → Clear Handoffs → Stay Engaged → Close the Loop
  Step 1: Understand Who Owns What. You (PM): What to build and why. Problem definition, requirements, success criteria, prioritization. Engineering: How to build it. Architecture, code, infrastructure, technical decisions. Data science: How to make the AI work. Model selection, prompt engineering, calibration, statistical analysis.
  Step 2: Bring Problems, Not Solutions. Don't tell them HOW to do their job. Tell them WHAT problem you're solving. Bad: "Build me a database table with these 15 fields." Good: "I need to answer these questions. What data would we need, and what's the best way to structure it?"
  Step 3: Define Clear Handoffs. Be clear about what you're handing off and what you need back. "Here's the rubric with scoring criteria and examples. Here are 100 conversations with human scores. I need you to implement the LLM-as-judge and get to 85% alignment. Let me know if anything is unclear."
  Step 4: Stay Engaged Without Micromanaging. After handoff, don't disappear. Check in regularly. Ask if they're blocked. Be available for decisions. But don't hover or second-guess their technical decisions.
  Step 5: Close the Loop. When delivered, review it. Does it meet requirements? If not, give clear feedback. Not "this isn't good enough." Instead: "Alignment is 70%, we need 85%. The LLM seems too generous on resolution. Can we add more examples of partial resolution?"
  The Key Insight: Partnership works when everyone understands their role, handoffs are clear, and communication is specific.
  MENTAL MODEL 10: HANDLING AMBIGUITY
  Use when: You don't have enough information to make a confident decision.
  Name It → Reduce If Possible → Cost of Being Wrong → Make a Bet → Create Feedback Loops
  Step 1: Name What You Don't Know. Be specific. Not "I don't know what to do." Instead: "I don't know whether customers want feature A or feature B." Or: "I don't know if 80% accuracy is good enough to launch."
  Step 2: Ask If You Can Reduce Ambiguity Quickly. Talk to customers? Look at data? Run a quick test? Ask an expert? If you can reduce ambiguity quickly and cheaply, do it. But don't let research become an excuse to avoid deciding.
  Step 3: Ask What Happens If You're Wrong. If cost is low and reversible: Decide quickly, learn, adjust. If cost is high and irreversible: Invest more time reducing ambiguity.
  Step 4: Make a Bet and State Your Assumptions. "I'm prioritizing feature A over B. My assumption is customers care more about accuracy than speed. If we learn that's wrong, we'll pivot to B next quarter." This forces clarity and tells others what would change your mind.
  Step 5: Create Feedback Loops. What metric would tell you if you were right? When will you check? What would make you reconsider?
  The Key Insight: Most PM decisions are made with incomplete information. The skill isn't avoiding ambiguity. It's making reasonable decisions despite ambiguity, and learning quickly whether you were right.
  MENTAL MODEL 11: EXPLAINING TECHNICAL CONCEPTS
  Use when: You need to help a non-technical person understand something complex.
  Start with Why They Care → Use Analogies → Build Simple to Complex → Connect Back
  Step 1: Start with the Problem, Not the Solution. Don't start with "LLM-as-judge is a system that uses large language models..." Start with: "Customers want to know if their Virtual Agent is doing a good job. We handle millions of conversations. We can't have humans review every one. So we need an automated way to evaluate quality at scale." Now the solution makes sense.
  Step 2: Use Analogies. Connect to something familiar. "The LLM-as-judge is like having a really smart intern trained on our quality rubric. We show them a conversation and ask 'how would you rate this?' Except instead of one intern reviewing a few conversations, we have a system that can review millions instantly."
  Step 3: Build from Simple to Complex. Don't explain everything at once. Layer 1: "We have an AI that reads conversations and scores them on quality." Layer 2 (if they want more): "It scores on multiple dimensions: accuracy, tone, resolution." Layer 3 (if they want more): "We calibrate it against human judgment." Stop when they have what they need.
  Step 4: Connect Back to What They Care About. For an executive: "This means we can give customers real-time visibility into quality without scaling our QA team." For a customer: "This means you can see quality scores for every conversation, not just a sample."
  The Key Insight: Technical explanations fail when they're too detailed too fast, or when they don't connect to what the listener cares about.
  MENTAL MODEL 12: BEHAVIORAL STORIES (STAR FRAMEWORK)
  Use when: You're asked "tell me about a time" questions.
  Situation → Task → Action → Result
  Situation: Set context briefly. Where were you? What was the project? What was the challenge? Two to three sentences.
  Task: What was YOUR specific responsibility? Not the team. What were you accountable for? One to two sentences.
  Action: What did YOU do? This is the meat. Be specific about steps you took, decisions you made, how you worked with others. 60% of your answer time.
  Result: What happened? Quantify if possible. What did you learn? One to three sentences.
  Structure: Total time 90 seconds to 2 minutes. Situation + Task: 20%. Action: 60%. Result: 20%.
  Common Mistakes: Too much situation (get to the action). Saying "we" instead of "I" (be specific about your contribution). No result (always land with an outcome). Vague action (give specifics, not generalities).
  The Key Insight: Behavioral stories need to be prepared in advance. You need to know which experiences map to which question types, and you need to have practiced telling them.
  END OF MENTAL MODELS
  Save this. Reference it when preparing. Ready to move to item 6 (making evaluation explainable) or skip to Kunik scenarios?
title: Zoom Prep

text:
## 10. Questions to ask Dhivya
  1. "What does success look like for the evaluation system in the next 6-12 months?"
  This shows you're thinking about impact, not just tasks. Her answer tells you what she's prioritizing—is it improving LLM-as-judge accuracy? Launching new dimensions? Scaling to more customers? It also gives you a chance to connect your experience to what she needs.
  2. "What are the biggest challenges the team is facing right now with evaluation quality or calibration?"
  This is a genuine question that shows you understand the work is hard. Her answer tells you where the pain is—maybe alignment is drifting, maybe customers don't trust the scores, maybe certain dimensions are harder to calibrate. You can briefly connect to similar challenges you faced at Kunik if relevant.
  3. "How does the evaluation team work with the rest of product and engineering? What does that collaboration look like day-to-day?"
  This shows you care about how the work actually gets done, not just what the work is. Since she's data science and you'd be PM, understanding the collaboration model matters. It also signals you know how to work with technical teams, which is what she's evaluating.
