text:
## 11. Mock interview practice
  Tell me about a time you had to define what "quality" means for a system.
  Tell me about a time you worked with engineering or data science to fix a technical problem.
  Question 1: How would you build a rubric for a subjective dimension like tone?
  "Tone is tricky because it's subjective. If I just score 'tone: good or bad,' two people will disagree because they have different standards. So the way I'd approach it is to break tone into specific, observable sub-dimensions.
  When I look at a conversation with bad tone, I ask: what specifically is wrong? Is the bot ignoring that the customer is upset? Is it too cheerful for a serious problem? Is it using jargon the customer doesn't understand? Each of those is a different failure mode.
  So I'd break tone into four sub-dimensions: Empathy—did the bot acknowledge the customer's emotional state when appropriate? Professionalism—was the language appropriate for a business context? Tone match—did the tone fit the situation? Clarity—was the response easy to understand?
  For each sub-dimension, I'd go through the same rubric process. Pull 50-100 conversations, sort into piles, examine what makes the good ones good, write scoring criteria with specific examples. Test with multiple raters, refine where we disagree until we hit 85% agreement. Then hand to data science to implement the LLM-as-judge and calibrate until LLM matches humans.
  The key is you're not scoring something vague like 'tone.' You're scoring specific, observable behaviors that raters can agree on."
  Question 2: How would you calibrate an LLM-as-judge?
  "Calibration is making sure the LLM-as-judge scores conversations the same way humans would. The target is 85% or higher alignment.
  The process: First, I create a ground truth set. I take 100-200 conversations, have three humans score them independently using the rubric, and where two or more agree, that's the consensus score.
  Then I run the LLM-as-judge against the same conversations. I compare LLM scores to human scores and measure alignment—what percentage match?
  If alignment is below 85%, I analyze the disagreements. Is the LLM too generous? Too harsh? Confused by specific patterns? I categorize the disagreements.
  Then I work with data science to adjust the prompts. If the LLM is too generous on empathy, we add examples of what partial empathy looks like—not just good and bad, but the middle. If the LLM misses multi-turn context, we add instructions to evaluate the full conversation.
  Re-run, re-measure. It usually takes three to five rounds. At Kunik, we went from 70% to 78% to 86% over three iterations.
  After deployment, calibration isn't finished. Weekly, I'd pull 20 random conversations, have a human score them, compare to LLM. Monthly, calculate alignment on a larger sample. If alignment drops below 80%, investigate and recalibrate."
  Question 3: What do you do when the LLM-as-judge and humans disagree?
  "First, I don't assume either is right. I investigate the specific disagreements.
  I pull every conversation where they disagreed and look for patterns. Is the LLM consistently too generous on a specific dimension? Is it confused by a specific type of conversation? Is it interpreting a criterion differently than intended?
  Sometimes the LLM is wrong—the prompt isn't clear enough or doesn't have the right examples. I work with data science to adjust the prompt and re-run.
  Sometimes the human is wrong—they weren't following the rubric correctly, or the rubric itself is ambiguous. I refine the rubric language and retrain the human raters.
  Sometimes it's genuinely ambiguous—reasonable people could disagree. For those cases, I make a judgment call on how we want to handle it, document that decision, and add it to the rubric as guidance.
  The key is categorizing the disagreements. Random disagreements are fine—that's noise. Systematic disagreements mean something is broken and needs fixing."
  Question 4: Accuracy dropped 5% across multiple customers. How would you investigate?
  "If it's across multiple customers, that suggests a systemic issue—something in Zoom's platform, not one customer's configuration.
  First, I segment to find WHERE the problem is. Is it all channels or just voice? Is it all topics or specific topics? Is it all time periods or did it start on a specific date? I'm looking for the pattern that isolates the problem.
  Let's say I find it's voice only, and it started Tuesday. Now I have a hypothesis: something changed in the voice pipeline on Tuesday.
  Next, I trace through the voice pipeline to find WHY. The stages are transcription, intent recognition, retrieval, response generation, speech synthesis. I sample failed conversations and trace each one. Did transcription mishear the customer? Did intent recognition misunderstand? Did retrieval pull the wrong articles?
  Let's say I find transcription errors spiked—certain words are being misheard. I check with engineering: did anything change Tuesday? Maybe they deployed a transcription update to improve speed, but it degraded accuracy for certain accents.
  Once I've validated the root cause, I identify the fix and owner. This is an engineering fix—roll back the update or tune it. I document the impact, push for prioritization, and add this failure mode to our monitoring so we catch it faster next time."
  Question 5: A customer says your evaluation scores are wrong. How do you handle that?
  "First, I take it seriously. If customers don't trust the evaluation system, they don't trust the product.
  I ask them to share the specific conversations they think are scored wrong. I pull those conversations and review them myself, comparing the bot's responses to the source documents.
  Usually I find a mix. Some conversations the customer is right—there are real evaluation failures. Some the customer misunderstood what we're measuring. Some are genuinely ambiguous.
  For the real failures, I dig into why. At Kunik, when a customer said our accuracy scores were wrong, I found three root causes: retrieval failures where the wrong articles were pulled and the LLM-as-judge only saw the wrong articles, incomplete answers being scored as fully accurate because the rubric didn't distinguish completeness, and stale knowledge base content where the bot was technically accurate against the source but the source was outdated.
  For each root cause, I identify a fix. Add retrieval relevance as a separate check. Update the rubric to distinguish complete from incomplete. Add guidance that accuracy is measured against the knowledge base, not the real world.
  Then I communicate back to the customer. I acknowledge their concern was valid, explain what I found, share the fixes I'm implementing. They feel heard, they understand the nuance, and they're willing to give the system another chance."
  Question 6: How would you measure resolution quality for a Virtual Agent?
  "Resolution is tricky because it's not just 'did the bot give a correct answer'—it's 'did the customer's problem actually get solved.'
  The challenge is you can't always tell from the transcript. The bot might say 'I've submitted your refund request' but you don't know if the refund actually happened.
  So I'd reframe the dimension. I'm not measuring whether the real-world problem was solved—I can't know that from the transcript. I'm measuring whether the bot did everything within its power to address the customer's need.
  I'd define three outcomes: Fully resolved—the bot addressed the customer's stated need completely. The customer would have no reason to call back. Partially resolved—the bot addressed some but not all of the need, or started a process but didn't confirm completion. The customer might need to follow up. Not resolved—the bot failed to address the need entirely.
  I'd also add 'appropriate escalation' as a fourth category. If the issue genuinely required human judgment and the bot transferred to an agent, that's not a failure—that's correct behavior.
  Then I'd validate with a proxy metric: repeat contact rate. If resolution scores are high but customers are calling back at a high rate, the evaluation is wrong. High resolution plus low repeat contact means we're measuring the right thing."
  Question 7: What's the relationship between traditional contact center metrics and AI evaluation metrics?
  "Traditional metrics tell you WHAT happened. AI metrics tell you WHY.
  Traditional metrics like containment rate, CSAT, and first contact resolution measure business outcomes. Did customers get helped? Did they escalate? Were they satisfied? These have existed for decades because contact centers have always needed to measure operational performance.
  AI metrics like accuracy, intent recognition, retrieval relevance, and transcription accuracy measure the quality of the AI system itself. They're diagnostic. When containment drops, AI metrics tell you which stage of the pipeline is failing.
  You need both. If I only have traditional metrics, I know containment dropped 10% but I don't know what to fix. Is it a transcription problem? A retrieval problem? A generation problem? I'm guessing.
  If I only have AI metrics, I might be optimizing technical scores that don't actually connect to customer outcomes. Accuracy could be 95% but if the bot isn't resolving issues, customers are still unhappy.
  The flow is: traditional metrics identify WHERE the problem is, AI metrics diagnose WHY. Containment dropped for billing questions—that's the WHERE. Intent recognition for billing is fine, but retrieval relevance dropped—wrong knowledge articles are being pulled. That's the WHY. Now I know what to fix."
  Question 8: How would you organize metrics for different stakeholders?
  "Different stakeholders care about different things, so I'd organize in layers.
  Executive layer—VPs and C-level. They ask 'Is this working? Should we invest more?' They see outcome metrics only: containment rate, CSAT, trends over time, benchmark comparisons. One screen, 30-second glance, big numbers with red/yellow/green indicators. They don't need diagnostic details.
  Operations layer—contact center managers and team leads. They ask 'What's working, what's broken, where should we focus?' They see outcomes plus diagnostics broken down by topic, channel, time period. 'Containment is 68% overall, but billing is 54% while password resets are 91%.' That tells them where to focus. They don't need deep system metrics.
  Technical layer—product managers, engineering, data science. They ask 'What's technically broken and how do we fix it?' They see all three: outcomes, diagnostics, and system health. Transcription accuracy, intent recognition rates, retrieval relevance, confidence distributions, drill-down to specific conversations.
  The dashboard should let users move between layers. An executive sees containment is down, clicks to see it's billing, clicks again to see retrieval relevance dropped for billing topics. They can drill as deep as they want, but they start at the level appropriate for them."
  Question 9: Voice accuracy is consistently lower than chat. How would you diagnose that?
  "Voice has two additional pipeline stages that chat doesn't have: transcription at the start and speech synthesis at the end. That's where I'd focus.
  I'd pull the data. Let's say voice accuracy is 76% and chat accuracy is 89%. That's a 13-point gap. I'd segment voice failures by failure type.
  I trace through the voice pipeline for a sample of failures: transcription, intent recognition, retrieval, response generation, speech synthesis. For each failure, which stage broke?
  Let's say I find: 31% of voice failures are transcription errors—the system misheard the customer. 28% are intent recognition—heard correctly but misunderstood. 22% are response generation. 19% are speech synthesis—the response was correct but sounded wrong.
  Now I dig into transcription since that's my biggest category. What's causing the errors? I sample 100 transcription failures and categorize: background noise 23%, customer accent 34%, speaking too fast 18%, technical jargon 15%, audio quality 10%.
  Accent is the biggest. I'd propose mitigations: when transcription confidence is low, have the bot ask for clarification rather than guessing. Build custom vocabulary for each customer's product names and terms. Add voice-specific evaluation dimensions to the dashboard so customers can see transcription accuracy separately.
  The diagnosis tells me where to focus engineering effort and what voice-specific improvements would have the biggest impact."
  Question 10: How would you know if your evaluation system is working correctly?
  "Three ways: alignment monitoring, outcome correlation, and customer feedback.
  First, alignment monitoring. Weekly, I pull 20 random conversations, have a human score them, compare to LLM-as-judge scores. Is alignment holding at 85%+? If it drops, something changed—maybe conversation patterns shifted, maybe the rubric needs updating. Monthly, I do this on a larger sample to track trends.
  Second, outcome correlation. If the evaluation system is working, scores should correlate with real outcomes. High accuracy scores should correlate with lower repeat contact rates. High resolution scores should correlate with higher CSAT. If accuracy scores are high but customers keep calling back, the evaluation is measuring the wrong thing.
  Third, customer feedback. Are customers trusting the scores? Are they using the dashboard to make decisions? Or are they saying 'your scores don't match what we see'? Customer complaints are a signal that something might be off, even if my metrics look fine. When a customer pushes back, I investigate—sometimes they're wrong, sometimes they reveal a blind spot in the evaluation.
  If all three are healthy—alignment holding, outcomes correlating, customers trusting—the evaluation system is working. If any of the three breaks down, I investigate."
  That's 10 high-probability technical questions with polished answers. These are the kinds of questions Ram and Daniel asked, so Dhivya will likely go in similar directions.
  Want to do rapid-fire practice where I ask and you answer in your own words?
  Behavioral Question 1: "Tell me about a time you had to define quality metrics or build an evaluation system."
  
Situation:
"At Kunik, we built a RAG pipeline for financial data—developers would ask questions in plain English and get structured JSON back. We had a working system, but I was eyeballing results. Some looked good, some looked off, and I couldn't answer basic questions: What's our accuracy? Which query types fail most? Without measurement, I was guessing."
Task:
"I needed to define what 'accurate' actually meant so we could measure systematically. Without that definition, quality was subjective—I'd say something looked fine, my engineer would disagree, and we had no way to resolve it."
Action:
"I built a rubric from scratch. I pulled 50-100 query results and just looked at them without scoring. Then I sorted them into piles—clearly good, clearly bad, somewhere in the middle—using my gut.
I examined the piles. What made the good ones good? All the right companies, correct data, matched the query criteria. What made the bad ones bad? Wrong companies, wrong values, missing results. I wrote scoring criteria based on those patterns. Score 3 means all records match criteria with correct data. Score 2 means minor issues. Score 1 means significant errors.
I tested the criteria on 20 new results to see if they held up. Then I had Dharani, my PM support, score 50 results independently using the rubric. We compared scores. Where we disagreed—about 29% of the time—we discussed why. Usually the rubric wasn't specific enough for that situation. I refined the language, added edge case guidance, and we re-scored until we hit 86% agreement."
Result:
"That rubric let us measure systematically for the first time. Our baseline was 78% accuracy—which told us we had real work to do. But more importantly, we could now see the problem and diagnose where failures were happening. That rubric was the foundation for everything that came after."

  Behavioral Question 2: "Tell me about a time you worked with engineering or data science to solve a problem.
  
Situation:
"At Kunik, after building the evaluation system, we measured 78% accuracy. I diagnosed the failures and found 70% happened before the AI even generated anything—46% were retrieval problems like keyword mismatches, 24% were chunking problems where context was split across chunks. I needed engineering to fix these, but I had to give them clear direction."
Task:
"My job was to define what was broken and what success looked like. Their job was to figure out the technical solution. I couldn't just say 'fix retrieval'—that's too vague to act on."
Action:
"I wrote requirements for my engineer Sajal. For each fix, I described the problem specifically: '36% of failures are keyword mismatch. The system requires exact matches but the same concept can be expressed different ways—APAC versus Asia-Pacific, healthtech versus medical technology.'
I gave concrete examples: 'This query for APAC companies should have returned Company C, but didn't because the chunk said Asia-Pacific instead of APAC.' I quantified the impact: 'This affects roughly 95 queries, 36% of all failures.' I defined success criteria: 'After the fix, queries for APAC should find documents mentioning Asia-Pacific, Asia Pacific, APAC region.'
Sajal implemented hybrid search—combining keyword and semantic search. I validated by re-running the queries I had diagnosed. Company C was now found. But Company D was still missing.
I dug in and found the semantic search had found the right chunk, but it was ranking too low. I brought that back to Sajal: 'Company D is still missing. Semantic search found it but the ranking is off.' He adjusted the weighting. I tested again. Now Company G was incorrectly appearing—semantic search was too broad.
We went back and forth like this—test, find gaps, adjust, test again—until we found the right balance."
Result:
"After all four fixes—hybrid search, chunking optimization, reranking, and routing—we went from 78% to 96% accuracy. The key learning was that iteration is normal. Fixes rarely work perfectly the first time. My job was to validate and bring clear feedback. His job was to figure out the technical solution. That division of responsibility made the collaboration work."

  Behavioral Question 3: "Tell me about a time you had to diagnose why something wasn't working."

  Situation:
"At Kunik, we measured 78% accuracy on our RAG pipeline. I knew we needed 90%+ for financial customers to trust the data. But 78% is just a number—it doesn't tell you what to fix. I had 264 failed queries out of 1,200 and no idea why they were failing."
Task:
"I needed to figure out where in the pipeline failures were happening. Without diagnosis, we'd be guessing at fixes—maybe wasting engineering time on the wrong things."
Action:
"I sampled 50 failed queries across different query types. For each one, I traced through our five-stage pipeline: Query Analysis, Retrieval, Relevance Check, Reranking, Synthesis.
For each failure, I asked: Did Query Analysis understand the query correctly? I'd check—yes, it extracted the right entities and filters. Were the right chunks retrieved? I'd look at what came back—no, Company C should have been found but wasn't. Why? The query said 'APAC' but the chunk said 'Asia-Pacific.' Keyword mismatch.
I categorized failures as patterns emerged. After 50 queries, I had a clear breakdown: 46% were retrieval problems—keyword mismatches and wrong sources searched. 24% were chunking problems—relevant information existed but was split across chunks so the system couldn't connect company names to valuations. 18% were generation problems—the AI hallucinated or extracted the wrong values from correct chunks.
I extrapolated to the full failure set: roughly 120 failures from retrieval, 63 from chunking, 48 from generation."
Result:
"The insight changed everything. 70% of failures happened before the AI even generated anything. That told me to focus engineering on retrieval and chunking, not on tweaking AI prompts. Without that diagnosis, we might have spent weeks on prompt engineering when the real problem was upstream. That's what enabled us to go from 78% to 96%."
Those are your three behavioral STAR stories for the most likely behavioral questions in a technical interview. They're ready to go.
title: Zoom Prep

text:
## THE FRAMEWORK FOR ANY ANSWER
1. Headline first - What's the point? Say it in one sentence.
2. Context - What do they need to know to understand this?
3. Specifics - What actually happened? Numbers, examples, details.
4. So what - Why did it matter? What was the outcome or learning?
title: Wellfoundary on demand interivew

text:
## WELLFOUND INTERVIEW ONE-PAGER
INTRO
I'm a product manager with about 12 years of experience, primarily in AI and data products.
Most recently I was Founder in Residence at Temasek's venture studio where I built Kunik from the ground up. Before that I co-founded Imbr - we reduced songwriter payment cycles from two years to 30 days. And at Warner Chappell I managed royalty platforms processing about $2B annually across 40 territories.
The common thread is building products in complex data environments where measuring quality is difficult and the output has to work for real people. I've done the zero-to-one work twice as a founder. That's where I operate best.
WHAT ARE YOU LOOKING FOR
I want to own something end to end. Direct access to customers, a team that makes decisions and ships. Early stage or growth can both work - what matters is the problem is substantive, the team is strong, and there's momentum.
DEAL BREAKERS
Places where product doesn't have real ownership. Where you're assembling tickets from stakeholder requests instead of solving problems. I recognize that environment quickly - it's not where I do good work.
EARLY STAGE VS GROWTH
Early stage I like being in the room when you're determining what to build. Talking to customers, making bets, learning fast. Growth I like seeing whether something works at scale - real numbers, real patterns, connecting what you built to outcomes.
What I want to avoid is the middle - large enough that everything moves slow, small enough that nothing you ship has real impact.
ACHIEVEMENT
I improved accuracy from 78% to 96% on a RAG system for financial data. That's what got us to $150K in design partner commitments - developers wouldn't pay until they could trust the data for investment decisions.
Context: Kunik was a two-sided marketplace connecting AI developers with licensed financial data. Developers query in plain English - "AI healthtech startups in APAC over $500M" - and get structured data back. They're making investment decisions on this. Wrong data is worse than no data.
78% wasn't good enough. The assumption was AI hallucinations - tune the prompts, adjust the model. I wasn't convinced. I pulled 50 failed queries and traced each one through the pipeline stage by stage. 70% of failures were retrieval - the system was pulling wrong documents before the AI ever processed them. Keyword mismatches, chunking that split relevant context.
Once I had that diagnosis, I wrote specific requirements - not "improve retrieval" but concrete examples of failures with clear success criteria. Worked with my engineer in tight cycles. I'd validate, identify what's still failing, bring it back with specifics.
I owned diagnosis and measurement. He owned implementation. That's how we reached 96% in months.
ENVIRONMENT
I need ownership over something real - not executing decisions someone else made. Direct access to customers so I can validate whether what I'm building works. And momentum.
On team dynamics - I work closely with engineers. Collaborative and iterative, not handoffs. I bring the problem with specifics, they determine the approach, we iterate. At Kunik my engineer and I went back and forth constantly - I'd test, find what's broken, he'd adjust. That's how we moved fast.
COLLABORATION
I owned diagnosis and measurement. My engineer owned implementation.
In practice: I traced failures, identified patterns, documented specific examples with clear success criteria. He built the technical solution. I validated against my test set - what's resolved, what's still failing, why. Back to him with specifics. Two week cycles.
That structure worked because there was no ambiguity. He wasn't guessing what "fix accuracy" meant. I wasn't waiting months for a release. We knew what was broken, so we fixed that.
PRECISION VS RECALL
For financial data, precision takes priority. Incorrect data leads to bad investment decisions - that's harmful. Incomplete data is frustrating but doesn't mislead.
So I prioritized precision first. Tightened relevance filtering - fewer results, but reliable. The tradeoff was recall dropped. We were missing valid companies because "APAC" wouldn't match "Asia-Pacific" in the documents.
Then we implemented hybrid search to recover recall without compromising precision. That sequence mattered - establish precision first, then recover recall systematically. That's how we reached 96%.
BIGGEST HURDLE TO 96%
Determining where the problem actually was. The assumption was AI hallucinations - prompts, model issues. I couldn't confirm otherwise until I traced through the failures myself.
I pulled 50 failed queries, went stage by stage. 70% were retrieval - wrong documents before the AI ever saw them.
Once I knew that, the path was clear. The hurdle wasn't fixing it - it was knowing what to fix.
WHAT I DELIVERED
The diagnosis was my work. Traced failures, identified patterns, found the 70% retrieval issue.
Wrote requirements for each fix - specific, with examples and success criteria. Defined the test set. Ran validation after each fix. Identified what's still broken, brought it back.
My engineer built the technical solutions to my specs. I validated whether they worked.
I owned the what and the measurement. He owned the how.
TIME BREAKDOWN
Diagnosis was front-loaded - about two weeks tracing failures, categorizing patterns.
Then iterative. He ships a fix, I validate for a day or two. Identify what's passing, what's broken. Find the pattern, document it, bring it back.
Roughly 30% diagnosis, 50% validation cycles, 20% requirements. Not clean - some days debugging specific failures, some days documenting patterns, some days running queries.
The key was staying close to actual failures. In the data constantly, not managing from a distance.
TYPICAL DAY / TOOLS / SKILLS
Right now I'm consulting - market mapping, customer discovery calls, synthesizing for clients.
When I was building Kunik it was different. Mornings usually customer calls, afternoons building or with my engineer. Constant loop - talk to customer, learn something, change the product, validate.
Two skills I developed:
Evaluation systems. Before Kunik I didn't have a framework for measuring whether AI was working. Now I've built rubrics, understand precision and recall tradeoffs, calibration methodology, alignment between human and LLM scoring. At Kunik I had to define what "accurate" means for financial data. That's not straightforward.
I build directly now. Not just specifications and handoffs. I built a contract review tool on the side - Claude for the AI layer, Claude Code for development, Vercel for deployment, GitHub for version control. Concept to working prototype in a weekend. That changes my conversations with engineering - I can demonstrate rather than describe, and I understand constraints because I've encountered them.
Tools: Claude for research, analysis, writing, code. Claude Code and Cursor for building. Vercel and GitHub for deployment. Notion for organization. Figma when I need mockups.
MAPPING MARKETS TIME SINK
Structuring. Getting data isn't difficult anymore. The difficult part is making sense of it - what categories matter, what's signal versus noise, how to frame it so someone can decide.
TOUGH TRADEOFF
Pausing Kunik. We had $150K committed, 96% accuracy, publishers signing LOIs. Going to market with public data and some proprietary partnerships.
The core value was paywalled data in one place. Then Anthropic announced MCP - commoditized public finance data that's already structured for RAG. Anyone can plug that in now.
So our differentiation depends entirely on proprietary partnerships. Long sales cycles. We had LOIs but needed more locked in. Six months of runway.
The choice: continue burning capital hoping partnerships close in time, or pause and preserve what's left.
I paused. Hardest decision I've made. But exhausting runway while pretending the market hasn't shifted - that's worse.
SKILLS I DEVELOPED
Evaluation systems. Before Kunik I didn't have a framework for measuring whether AI was working. Now I've built rubrics, understand precision and recall, calibration, alignment between human and LLM scoring. Defining what "accurate" means for financial data isn't obvious. That discipline is central to how I approach AI products now.
I build directly. Not just specifications. I built a contract review tool - Claude, Claude Code, Vercel, GitHub. Concept to working prototype in a weekend. Changes how I work with engineering - I demonstrate rather than describe, and I understand constraints because I've hit them.
TOOLS
Claude for research, analysis, writing, code. Claude Code and Cursor for building. Vercel and GitHub for deployment. Notion for organization. Figma for mockups.
title: Wellfoundary on demand interivew

text:
##  HYPOTHETICALS — ZILLOW BRIDGES
  "How would you apply what you learned at Kunik to what we're building?"
  Core transfer: building AI that takes actions in high-stakes decisions requires earning trust incrementally
  At Kunik, accuracy was the trust threshold — users didn't trust it until 96%
  At Zillow, same principle but different threshold — users won't let AI schedule tours or draft offers until they've seen it get smaller things right first
  Also: compliance as foundation, not afterthought. Built data provenance into Kunik from day one. At Zillow, fair housing considerations need the same treatment — baked into architecture, not bolted on
  "Where would you start if you joined this team tomorrow?"
  First 30 days: diagnose. Where is the team on the trust escalation ladder with users? Where are the biggest failure modes right now?
  Understand the agent relationship — is AI seen as augmenting agents or threatening them? That shapes everything
  Look for high-frequency, lower-stakes actions as starting point — want lots of reps to learn from, but room to make mistakes
  Tour scheduling might be a good early bet. Offer submission would not — too high stakes before trust is established
  "What failure modes would you be most worried about?"
  Confidence miscalibration — AI acts confident when it should be uncertain, user trusts it and gets burned. Most dangerous because users can't catch it
  Multi-party coordination failures — AI promises something to buyer that agent didn't confirm. Now you have broken expectations across relationships
  Timing failures — AI acts too fast (before user was ready) or too slow (misses opportunity)
  Framework for prioritizing: frequency × severity × detectability. Fix the high-frequency, high-severity, low-detectability failures first
  "How would you think about trust with users in this domain?"
  Trust is earned gradually, can't be assumed
  Start with suggestions, not actions. "Here are three properties you might like" before "I scheduled tours for these"
  Let users verify before acting. "I drafted this message to the agent — want me to send it?"
  Trust escalation ladder: awareness → trial → verification → delegation → reliance
  Design for the anxious user first — more checkpoints, more transparency. Let power users dial down friction later
  "How would you measure success for agentic AI?"
  Ultimate outcome is months away (did they buy a home, did AI help)
  Need leading indicators: task completion rate, user acceptance rate (accept/modify/reject AI suggestions), error rate, recovery rate (when AI makes mistake, does user recover or abandon), trust signals (are users giving AI more autonomy over time)
  Also qualitative: user feedback, support tickets, session recordings
  Feedback loops critical — need infrastructure to connect AI actions to outcomes so the system learns
  "How do you think about the agent relationship?"
  Two-sided marketplace dynamics — can't ignore supply side
  If agents see AI as threatening their value, they'll push back. If AI makes them more effective, they'll embrace it
  Key question: is AI replacing agent work or augmenting agent work?
  Frame as augmentation: AI handles tedious coordination, frees agent to focus on relationship and expertise
  Similar to Kunik — had to serve both developers and data providers. Can't optimize for one side without considering the other
title: Zillow interview prep

text:
## Imbr (Backup for "Own It" or "0→1 in Ambiguity") 
  The Core Story
  Context:
Songwriters typically wait 730 days (two years) to get paid royalties. The money flows through a chain — DSPs report usage, collection societies aggregate, publishers process, matching happens, disputes get resolved, then finally payment. Each step adds delay. This is an industry-wide problem that everyone accepts as "just how it works."
  The Insight:
At Imbr, you and your co-founder (the EVP of Digital from Warner, so he knew the contracts and partner side) realized the bottleneck wasn't the payment infrastructure — it was the validation process. Everyone waits for usage data to trigger validation of ownership. But ownership changes less frequently than usage. What if you validated ownership claims upfront, before usage data even arrived?
  What You Built:
A preclaim system. Rights holders register their claims with supporting documentation. You validate these in advance. When usage data arrives, payments can flow immediately to pre-validated recipients. You reduced payment cycles from 730 days to 30 days.
  Your Role:
Your co-founder handled contracts and partners. You built the entire product — giving engineers guidance, designing the matching tool (similar functionality to what you'd built at Warner), architecting the system.
  Why This Works for "Own It" or "0→1"
  For Own It: You took full ownership of the product side of a startup. Not "contributed to" — you built it.
  For 0→1 in Ambiguity: You looked at a broken system everyone accepted and reimagined it from first principles. Instead of optimizing the existing flow, you inverted it entirely.
  The Natural Way to Tell It (Short Version)
  When to Use This
  Use Imbr if Teresa asks:
  "Tell me about another time you owned something end-to-end"
  "Tell me about a time you tackled an ambiguous problem"
  "Tell me about a time you challenged conventional thinking"
  Don't use Imbr as your primary "Own It" story — Kunik is stronger because it's more recent and more directly relevant to AI product work. But Imbr is a solid backup that shows you've done this pattern multiple times.
title: Zillow interview prep

text:
## Fox Programmatic Revenue (Backup for "Influence Through Data" or "Delivering Results")
  Story 4: Fox Programmatic Revenue (Backup for "Influence Through Data" or "Delivering Results")
  The Core Story
  Context:
At Fox Entertainment, you managed digital properties serving 30 million users. You identified an opportunity in programmatic advertising optimization.
  What You Did:
You used data to identify where revenue was being left on the table in the ad stack. You built the case, aligned the stakeholders (ad ops, engineering, business teams), and drove the optimization.
  The Outcome:
$2M in incremental annual revenue within 6 months.
  The Harvey/TMZ Twist (if they ask about stakeholder conflict):
At TMZ, you increased incremental daily revenue by $2-3K. Harvey Levin wanted more engagement features — comments, polls — that would push ads down the page. You predicted this would hurt revenue. You suggested compromises, he didn't want them, they implemented his way, revenue dropped as you predicted, then they went back to your approach.
  The Natural Way to Tell It (Short Version)
title: Zillow interview prep

text:
Your intro (keep it under 60 seconds):
"I'm a Principal PM with 12 years in product, last 5 focused on AI/ML. Most recently I was Founder in Residence at Temasek's venture studio where I built an AI data marketplace from scratch - RAG pipelines, evaluation frameworks, took accuracy from 78% to 96%. Before that I spent nearly 3 years at Warner Chappell building royalty and media processing platforms handling $2B+ across 40 territories. I've also founded two companies. I saw Coactive and reached out to Satya because the multimodal AI space is exactly where I want to be - I just wanted to make sure we're aligned on level since the posted role looked a bit junior for my background."
Talking points to have ready:
Why Coactive:
Multimodal AI is where the market is going
Unstructured data (images/video) is a hard problem I find interesting
Series B, strong investors, small enough to have impact
Your relevant experience:
Built AI data pipelines (Kunik)
ML matching systems (Warner Chappell - 85% to 95% precision)
Enterprise customers in media/entertainment (their target vertical)
0-to-1 product building twice as founder
Questions to ask her:
What level is the team thinking for this role?
What does the PM team look like today?
What's the timeline for the interview process?
Is there flexibility to work from the SF office some days?
If she asks about comp:
"For SF-based at this level, I'm targeting $300K total comp."
Don't overcomplicate it. Be direct, confident, conversational. You've done this before.
Coactive AI in plain terms:
Companies have millions of images and videos sitting in storage - product photos, user-generated content, surveillance footage, media libraries. Right now that stuff is basically unsearchable unless someone manually tagged it.
Coactive lets you search and analyze all that visual content using natural language. "Show me all images with a red dress near a beach" - and it just works, no tagging required.
Their customers:
Fandom (45M wiki pages of visual content moderation)
Media & entertainment companies managing content libraries
Retail (searching product catalogs)
Trust & safety teams (finding policy violations in images/video at scale)
What the PM would do:
Work with enterprise customers to understand their pain points with visual data
Define what features to build next (better search? new integrations? faster processing?)
Collaborate with ML/engineering on how to ship it
Figure out how to make a deeply technical product feel simple to users
Probably own a specific surface area - could be the search experience, the API, the integrations, the tagging system
Your relevant experience:
Kunik: built AI that let people query complex data with natural language
Warner Chappell: massive catalog management, matching systems
Media & entertainment customers are their target vertical
On the call, you're feeling out:
What's the actual scope of this PM role?
Is there flexibility on level and comp?
Dog-friendly office?
SF vs San Jose flexibility?
$300K base is your target. Be yourself. You got this.
title: Coactive AI
